revision.text:
{{Year box}} '''1853 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
==[[Baseball]]== '''Events''' * The New York ''[[Sunday Mercury (New York)|Sunday Mercury]]'' publishes a box score for a [[New York Knickerbockers|Knickerbockers]]–Gothams baseball match, reprinted by the ''Clipper'' a few days later
==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * 18 April — English champion [[Harry Broome]] defeats [[Henry Orme]] in the 31st round at Brandon to retain his title.<ref name="HB">[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/broome-h.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – Harry Broome]. Retrieved on 8 November 2009.</ref> * August — a scheduled bout between Broome and former champion [[William Perry (boxer)|William Perry]] does not come off; Broome has to pay forfeit and Perry claims the title, but his claim is not recognised and Broome retains the English Championship until 1856.<ref name="HB"/> * 12 October — [[Yankee Sullivan]] and [[John Morrissey]] meet to decide the Heavyweight Championship of America at Boston Corners, New York. According to reports, Morrissey is "badly beaten" but Sullivan leaves the ring after the 37th round and ignores the call of "time". As a result, the referee awards the fight to Morrissey, who holds the American Championship until 1859. Sullivan does not fight again but is subsequently arrested in San Francisco and sent to jail.<ref name="JM">[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/morrisey.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – John Morrissey]. Retrieved on 8 November 2009.</ref> * Publication of the [[Revised London Prize Ring rules]]
==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * '''England''' * Most runs – [[Jemmy Dean]] 372 @ 12.82 (HS 62) * Most wickets – [[James Grundy (cricketer)|James Grundy]] 87 @ 10.04 (BB 8–?)
==[[Horse racing]]== * [[West Australian (horse)|West Australian]] wins the English [[Triple Crown of Thoroughbred Racing|Triple Crown]] with a clean sweep of the 2000 Guineas, the Derby and the St Leger '''England''' * [[1853 Grand National|Grand National]] – [[Peter Simple (horse)|Peter Simple]] (for the second time, having previously won in 1849) * [[1,000 Guineas Stakes]] – Mentmore Lass * [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[West Australian (horse)|West Australian]] * [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – [[West Australian (horse)|West Australian]] * [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] – Catherine Hayes * [[St. Leger Stakes]] – [[West Australian (horse)|West Australian]]
==[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]== '''The Boat Race''' * The [[Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race]] is not held this year
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Sports by year 1851 – 1900}}
[[Category:Sports by year]] [[Category:1853 in sports| ]]

{{Expand Portuguese|Pequena Taça do Mundo de 1954|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox International Football Competition | tourney_name = Small Club World Cup | year = 1953 | dates = July | image = | size = | caption = | country = Venezuela | num_teams = [[#Participant_teams|4]] | associations = 2 | venues = | cities = | champion_other = {{flagicon|BRA}} [[Sport Club Corinthians Paulista|Corinthians]] | count = 1 | matches = 12 | goals = 40 | top_scorer = | prevseason = [[1953 Small Club World Cup (1st tournament)|1953 (1st tournament)]] | nextseason = [[1955 Small Club World Cup|1955]] }} The '''1953 Small Club World Cup (2nd tournament)''' was the third edition of the [[Small Club World Cup]], a tournament held in Venezuela between 1952 and 1957, and in 1963 and in 1965. It was played by four participants, half from Europe and half from South America in double round robin format. This was the 2nd tournament played in the same year; none was held in the next calendar year. ==Final standings == {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" |- !width="165"|Team[http://www.rsssf.com/tablesp/peq-copamundo54.html Pequeña Copa del Mundo 1953 2nd Tournament] - RSSSF[http://www.citadini.com.br/alambrado/oexp020112.htm Jornal "O Expresso" - Alambrado][http://www.campeoesdofutebol.com.br/tab_pequena_cmundo54.html Pequena Copa do Mundo de Clubes 1953] - Campeões do Futebol !width="20"|Pts !width="20"|P !width="20"|W !width="20"|L !width="20"|D !width="20"|GF !width="20"|GA !width="20"|GD |-bgcolor=ccffcc |style="text-align:left;"|{{flagicon|BRA}} [[Sport Club Corinthians Paulista|Corinthians]] |'''12'''||6||6||0||0||12||4||8 |-bgcolor=pink |style="text-align:left;"|{{flagicon|ITA}} [[Associazione Sportiva Roma|Roma]] |'''5'''||6||2||3||1||9||10||-1 |-bgcolor=pink |style="text-align:left;"|{{flagicon|ESP}} [[Futbol Club Barcelona|Barcelona]] |'''4'''||6||2||4||0||10||13||-3 |-bgcolor=pink |style="text-align:left;"|{{flagicon|VEN}} Caracas XI |'''3'''||6||1||4||1||9||13||-4 |} ==Winners== {{refimprove|date=August 2014}} {| class="wikitable" style="margin: 0 auto; width: 20%;" |- !1953 Small Club World Cup |- |align=center|[[Image:Flag of Brazil.svg|100px]]

revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=June 2018}} '''1960 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
{{Year box}}
==[[Alpine skiing]]== * The men's [[1960 Winter Olympics|Olympic]] Gold Medal: ** Downhill: [[Jean Vuarnet]], France ** Slalom: [[Ernst Hinterseer]], Austria ** Giant Slalom: [[Roger Staub]], Switzerland ** The women's [[1960 Winter Olympics|Olympic]] Gold Medal: ** Downhill: [[Heidi Biebl]], [[West Germany]] ** Slalom: [[Ann Heggtveit]], Canada ** Giant Slalom: [[Yvonne Rüegg]], Switzerland * [[FIS Alpine World Ski Championships]]: ** Men's combined champion: [[Guy Périllat]], France ** Women's combined champion: [[Ann Heggtveit]], Canada, who becomes the first non-European to win a world championship title in [[Alpine skiing]].
==[[American football]]== * [[Cotton Bowl Classic|Cotton Bowl]] (1959 season): ** The [[Syracuse Orangemen]] won 23-17 over the [[Texas Longhorns]] to win the college football national championship * [[National Football League]] names [[Pete Rozelle]] commissioner of the league. The league expands to [[Dallas Cowboys|Dallas]] for the 1960 season and [[Minnesota Vikings|Minneapolis-St.Paul]] for the 1961 season. The [[Chicago Cardinals]] relocates to [[St. Louis]]. * December 26-[[1960 NFL Championship Game|NFL Championship]] – [[Philadelphia Eagles]] won 17-13 over the [[Green Bay Packers]] * The [[American Football League]] (AFL) played its first season * First black pro football placekicker: [[Gene Mingo]] ([[Denver Broncos]], [[American Football League|AFL]]) * First Hispanic pro football quarterback: [[Tom Flores]] ([[Oakland Raiders]], [[American Football League|AFL]]) * AFL Championship: [[Houston Oilers]] won 24-16 over the [[Los Angeles Chargers]]
==[[Association football]]== * [[FA Cup|England – FA Cup]] – [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] won 3-0 over [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]]<ref>{{cite web |title=FA Cup final: Wigan's Whelan makes poignant Wembley return |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/22466795 |website=BBC Sport |accessdate=25 June 2018 |date=9 May 2013}}</ref> * The [[USSR national football team|Soviet Union]] beat [[Yugoslavia national football team|Yugoslavia]] 2-1 to win the first [[1960 European Football Championship|European Football Championship]]
==[[Australian rules football]]== * [[Victorian Football League (1897–1989)|Victorian Football League]] ** [[Melbourne Football Club|Melbourne]] wins the 64th VFL Premiership to McDonalds (Melbourne 8.14 (62) d [[Collingwood Football Club|Collingwood]] 2.2 (14)) ** [[Brownlow Medal]] awarded to [[John Schultz (footballer, born 1938)|John Schultz]] ([[Footscray Football Club|Footscray]])
==[[Baseball]]== * [[World Series]] – [[Pittsburgh Pirates]] win 4 games to 3 over the [[New York Yankees]]. The Series MVP is New York's [[Bobby Richardson]]. * October 13 – [[1960 World Series]] Game 7 at [[Forbes Field]] – [[Pittsburgh Pirates]] player [[Bill Mazeroski]] becomes the first person to end a [[World Series]] with a [[home run]], and still the only player to do it in the decisive seventh game. * The [[Winnipeg Goldeyes]] win the [[Northern League (baseball, 1902–71)|Northern League]] championship.
==[[Basketball]]== '''NBA Finals''' *[[Boston Celtics]] win four games to three over the [[St. Louis Hawks]]
==[[Boxing]]== * March 16 – [[Flash Elorde]] won the world junior lightweight title with a seventh-round knockout of [[Harold Gomes]] in [[Quezon City]], [[Philippines]]. * June – [[Floyd Patterson]] recovered the world heavyweight title from [[Ingemar Johansson]], becoming the first-ever boxer to do so. * September 5 – [[Muhammad Ali|Cassius Clay]] wins the gold medal in [[boxing]] at the Rome [[Olympic Games]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Muhammad Ali: The ultimate fighter |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/timelines/zy3hycw |website=BBC Timelines |accessdate=25 June 2018 |language=en}}</ref>
==[[Canadian football]]== * [[Grey Cup]] – [[Ottawa Rough Riders]] defeated the [[Edmonton Eskimos]] 34-9 .
==[[Cycling]]== * [[1960 Tour de France|Tour de France]] – [[Gastone Nencini]] of Italy<ref>{{cite book |last1=Collection |first1=The Horton |title=Shoulder to Shoulder: Bicycle Racing in the Age of Anquetil |date=2015 |publisher=VeloPress |isbn=9781937716721 |page=182 |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=OPvGCgAAQBAJ&pg=PT182|language=en}}</ref> * [[1960 Giro d'Italia|Giro d'Italia]] – [[Jacques Anquetil]] of France
==[[Field hockey]]== * [[Hockey at the 1960 Summer Olympics|Olympic Games (Men's Competition)]] in Rome, Italy<ref>{{cite web |title=hockey men - Olympic Hockey |url=https://www.olympic.org/hockey/12-team-tournament-men |website=International Olympic Committee |accessdate=25 June 2018 |language=en |date=15 May 2018}}</ref> ** Gold Medal: Pakistan ** Silver Medal: India ** Bronze Medal: Spain
==[[Golf]]== '''Men's professional''' * [[1960 Masters Tournament|Masters Tournament]] – [[Arnold Palmer]] * [[1960 U.S. Open (golf)|U.S. Open]] – [[Arnold Palmer]] * [[1960 Open Championship|British Open]] – [[Kel Nagle]] * [[1960 PGA Championship|PGA Championship]] – [[Jay Hebert]] * [[PGA Tour]] money leader – [[Arnold Palmer]] – $75,263 '''Men's amateur''' * [[The Amateur Championship|British Amateur]] – [[Joe Carr]] * [[U.S. Amateur]] – [[Deane Beman]] '''Women's professional''' * [[Women's Western Open]] – [[Joyce Ziske]] * [[1960 LPGA Championship|LPGA Championship]] – [[Mickey Wright]] * [[1960 U.S. Women's Open Golf Championship|U.S. Women's Open]] – [[Betsy Rawls]] * [[Titleholders Championship]] – [[Fay Crocker]] * [[LPGA|LPGA Tour]] money leader – [[Louise Suggs]] – $16,892
==[[Harness racing]]== * [[Triple Crown of Harness Racing for Pacers|United States Pacing Triple Crown races]] – *# [[Cane Pace]] – [[Countess Adios]] *# [[Little Brown Jug (horse racing)|Little Brown Jug]] – [[Bullet Hanover]] *# [[Yonkers Trot]] *# [[Kentucky Futurity]] * [[Australian Inter Dominion Harness Racing Championship]] – ** Pacers: [[Caduceus]]
==[[Horse racing]]== [[Steeplechase (horse racing)|Steeplechase]]s * [[Cheltenham Gold Cup]] – [[Pas Seul]] * [[1960 Grand National|Grand National]] – [[Merryman II]]
[[National Hunt flat race|Flat races]] * Australia – [[Melbourne Cup]] won by * Canada – [[Queen's Plate]] won by [[Victoria Park (horse)|Victoria Park]] * France – [[Prix de l'Arc de Triomphe]] won by [[Puissant Chef]] * Ireland – [[Irish Derby Stakes]] won by [[Chamour]] * [[Triple Crown of Thoroughbred Racing|English Triple Crown Races]]: *# [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Martial (horse)|Martial]] *# [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – [[St. Paddy]] *# [[St. Leger Stakes]] – [[St. Paddy]] * [[Triple Crown of Thoroughbred Racing|United States Triple Crown Races]]: *# [[1960 Kentucky Derby|Kentucky Derby]] – [[Venetian Way]] *# [[1960 Preakness Stakes|Preakness Stakes]] – [[Bally Ache]] *# [[Belmont Stakes]] – [[Celtic Ash]]
==[[Ice hockey]]== * The American Olympic men's ice-hockey team won the United States' first [[1960 Winter Olympics|Olympic]] hockey gold medal with a record of 7–0–0 during the tournament. * [[Art Ross Trophy]] as the [[National Hockey League|NHL]]'s leading scorer during the regular season: [[Bobby Hull]], [[Chicago Blackhawks|Chicago Black Hawks]] * [[Hart Memorial Trophy]] for the [[National Hockey League|NHL]]'s Most Valuable Player: [[Gordie Howe]], [[Detroit Red Wings]] * [[1960 Stanley Cup Finals|Stanley Cup]] – [[Montreal Canadiens]] win 4 games to 0 over the [[Toronto Maple Leafs]] * [[World Hockey Championship]] ** Men's champion: United States is crushed by Canada * [[NCAA Men's Ice Hockey Championship]] – [[University of Denver]] Pioneers defeat [[Michigan Technological University]] Huskies 5-3 in [[Boston]]
==[[Motorsport]]== {{main|1960 in motorsport|List of 1960 motorsport champions}}
==[[Olympic Games]]== * [[1960 Summer Olympics]] held in Rome, Italy ** [[Soviet Union|USSR]] wins the most medals (103), and the most gold medals (43) * [[1960 Winter Olympics]] held in [[Squaw Valley, Placer County, California|Squaw Valley]], United States ** [[Soviet Union|USSR]] wins the most medals (21), and the most gold medals (7) * First [[1960 Summer Paralympics|Paralympic Games]] held in Rome, Italy ** Italy wins the most medals (80) and the most gold medals (29) * First [[1960 Winter Universiade|Winter Universiade]] held in [[Chamonix]], France
==[[Rugby league]]== *[[1960 New Zealand rugby league season]] *[[1959–60 Northern Rugby Football League season]] / [[1960–61 Northern Rugby Football League season]] *[[1960 NSWRFL season]] *[[1960 Rugby League World Cup]]
==[[Rugby union]]== * 66th [[1960 Five Nations Championship|Five Nations Championship]] series is shared by [[England national rugby union team|England]] and [[France national rugby union team|France]]
==[[Swimming (sport)|Swimming]]== * June 12 – [[Marianne Heemskerk]] from the Netherlands breaks the [[World record progression 200m butterfly|world record]] in the women's 200m butterfly during a meet in [[Leipzig]], [[East Germany]] – '''2:34.4'''. * July 10 – US swimmer [[Michael Troy]] breaks his own [[World record progression 200m butterfly|world record]] in the men's 200m butterfly (long course) at a meet in [[Evansville, Indiana]], clocking '''2:15.0'''. * July 23 – Thirteen days after breaking his own [[World record progression 200m butterfly|world record]] in the men's 200m butterfly (long course) Troy once again betters the world's best time in that event, this time at a meet in [[Toledo, Ohio|Toledo]], Ohio clocking '''2:13.4'''. * August 4 – Less than a month before the [[Swimming at the 1960 Summer Olympics|Summer Olympics]] in Rome, Italy, Troy again breaks the [[World record progression 200m butterfly|world record]] in the men's 200m butterfly (long course), when he clocks '''2:13.2''' at a meet in [[Detroit, Michigan|Detroit]], Michigan. * September 2 – Michael Troy wins the men's 200m butterfly (long course) at the [[Swimming at the 1960 Summer Olympics|Summer Olympics]] in Rome, Italy by breaking his own [[World record progression 200m butterfly|world record]] – '''2:12.8'''.
==[[Tennis]]== '''Australia''' * [[List of Australian Open Men's Singles champions|Australian Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Rod Laver]] (Australia) defeats [[Neale Fraser]] (Australia) 5–7, 3–6, 6–3, 8–6, 8–6 * [[List of Australian Open Women's Singles champions|Australian Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Margaret Smith Court]] (Australia) defeats [[Jan Lehane O'Neill]] (Australia) 7–5, 6–2 '''England''' * [[List of Wimbledon Gentlemen's Singles champions|Wimbledon Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Neale Fraser]] (Australia) defeats [[Rod Laver]] (Australia) 6–4, 3–6, 9–7, 7–5 * [[List of Wimbledon Ladies' Singles champions|Wimbledon Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Maria Bueno]] (Brazil) defeats [[Sandra Reynolds Price]] (South Africa) 8–6, 6–0 '''France''' * [[List of French Open Men's Singles champions and finalists|French Men's Singles Championship]] – * [[List of French Open Women's Singles champions|French Women's Singles Championship]] – '''USA''' * [[List of US Open Men's Singles champions|American Men's Singles Championship]] – * [[List of US Open Women's Singles champions|American Women's Singles Championship]] – '''Davis Cup''' * [[1960 Davis Cup]] – {{davis|AUS}} 4–1 {{davis|ITA}} at [[White City Stadium (Sydney)|White City Stadium]] (grass) [[Sydney]], Australia
==[[Volleyball]]== * [[1960 FIVB Men's World Championship]] in Rio de Janeiro won by the USSR
==Awards== * [[Associated Press Athlete of the Year#List of award winners|Associated Press Male Athlete of the Year]] – [[Rafer Johnson]], [[Track and field]] * [[Associated Press Athlete of the Year#List of award winners|Associated Press Female Athlete of the Year]] – [[Wilma Rudolph]], [[Track and field]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Sports by year 1951 – 2000}}
[[Category:Sports by year]] [[Category:1960 in sports| ]]

In the 2005–06 season of the '''Meore Liga''' (now [[Liga 3 (Georgia)|Liga 3]]), a third-tier [[Association football|football]] league in Georgia, the [[FC Norchi Dinamo Tbilisi]] team finished champions of the East Zone.

{{EngvarB|date=August 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2013}} {{Infobox cricket series |series= The Bicentennial Test |partof= |image= |caption= |date= 29 January 1988 – 2 February 1988 |place= Australia |result= Match Drawn |player of series= [[David Boon]] |team1= [[Image:Flag of England.svg|22px]] [[English cricket team|England]] |team2= [[Image:Flag of Australia.svg|22px]] [[Australian cricket team|Australia]] |captain1= [[Mike Gatting]] |captain2= [[Allan Border]] |runs1= 139 [[Chris Broad]] [[Image:Flag of England.svg|22px]] |runs2= 196 [[David Boon]] [[Image:Flag of Australia.svg|22px]] |wickets1= 3 [[Graham Dilley]] [[Image:Flag of England.svg|22px]]
3 [[Eddie Hemmings (cricketer)|Eddie Hemmings]] [[Image:Flag of England.svg|22px]] |wickets2= 4 [[Peter Taylor (Australian cricketer)|Peter Taylor]] [[Image:Flag of Australia.svg|22px]]
3 [[Steve Waugh]] [[Image:Flag of Australia.svg|22px]] }} The '''Bicentennial Test''' was a single [[Test cricket]] match played between [[Australian cricket team|Australia]] and [[English cricket team|England]] at the [[Sydney Cricket Ground]] in celebration of the [[Australian Bicentenary|bicentenary]] of permanent colonial settlement in Australia. The match took place from 29 January to 2 February 1988 and was drawn. It did not count as part of [[The Ashes]] series, in the same way as the [[Centenary Test]]s in 1977 and 1980 also were excluded from the Ashes lists. The match was played in the middle of an [[English cricket team in New Zealand in 1987-88|England tour]] to [[New Zealand cricket team|New Zealand]], where the team later played three Test matches, all of them also drawn. Previously the same winter, the England team had toured [[Pakistani cricket team|Pakistan]], and Australia had hosted Tests and [[One Day International]]s against New Zealand and [[Sri Lankan cricket team|Sri Lanka]] (the single Test against Sri Lanka came after the Bicentennial Test, but all other matches were before it). ==The teams== Sydney's reputation for favouring spin bowling led both sides to pick two specialist spin bowlers and to favour medium-pace or fast-medium bowling over out-and-out speed. England were captained by [[Mike Gatting]], fresh from his finger-wagging confrontation with [[umpire (cricket)|umpire]] [[Shakoor Rana]], and lacked several of the big name players of recent years, such as [[Graham Gooch]], [[David Gower]], [[Allan Lamb]], and [[Ian Botham]]. The team was, in batting order: * [[Chris Broad]] * [[Martyn Moxon]] * [[Tim Robinson (cricketer)|Tim Robinson]] * [[Mike Gatting]] (captain) * [[Bill Athey]] * [[David Capel]] * [[John Emburey]] * [[Bruce French (cricketer)|Bruce French]] (wicketkeeper) * [[Neil Foster]] * [[Eddie Hemmings (cricketer)|Eddie Hemmings]] * [[Graham Dilley]]. Australia were captained by [[Allan Border]]. The team, in batting order, was: * [[Geoff Marsh]] * [[David Boon]] * [[Dean Jones (cricketer)|Dean Jones]] * [[Allan Border]] (captain) * [[Mike Veletta]] * [[Steve Waugh]] * [[Peter Sleep]] * [[Greg Dyer]] (wicketkeeper) * [[Peter Taylor (Australian cricketer)|Peter Taylor]] * [[Tony Dodemaide]] * [[Craig McDermott]]. ==The match== England won the toss and batted. Broad shared stands of 93 with Moxon, who made 40, and 99 with Robinson, who made 43, on his way to a century on the first day. Wickets fell more steadily across the second day, including Broad for 139. Broad reacted angrily to his dismissal, and flattened the leg stump with his bat as he departed: he was fined the maximum permitted (£500) by the tour manager. England's final total of 425 contained no other scores of more than 50: the next highest after Broad was French with 47. On the third day, Australia batted poorly and lost wickets regularly to shots more suited to one-day cricket. Jones made 56, but when bad light ended play two hours early, the side was 164 for seven wickets, 62 runs short of the follow-on. In tense cricket on the fourth morning, they failed to reach that figure by 12 runs, and Gatting enforced the follow-on. With the pitch getting slower and easier, Marsh and Boon put up a first-wicket partnership of 162 and after Marsh went for 56, Boon batted on and on across the final day, eventually reaching 184 not out, his then-highest Test score, as Australia got to 328 for two to save the match. They were helped by the loss of more play to bad light (when Gatting recalled fast bowler Dilley to the attack), injuries to both Dilley and Foster and lack of penetration among the other England bowlers. The match was watched by 103,831 people, well below the forecast figure. ===Match statistics=== {{Test match | date = 29 January–2 February 1988 | team1 = {{cr-rt|ENG}} | team2 = {{cr|AUS}} | score-team1-inns1 = 425 (172.5 overs) | runs-team1-inns1 = [[Chris Broad]] 139 (361) | wickets-team1-inns1 = [[Peter Taylor (Australian cricketer)|Peter Taylor]] 4/84 (34 overs) | score-team2-inns1 = 214 (96.1 overs) | runs-team2-inns1 = [[Dean Jones (cricketer)|Dean Jones]] 56 (125) | wickets-team2-inns1 = [[Eddie Hemmings (cricketer)|Eddie Hemmings]] 3/53 (22 overs) | score-team1-inns2 = | runs-team1-inns2 = | wickets-team1-inns2 = | score-team2-inns2 = 328/2 (135 overs) ([[Follow-on|f/o]]) | runs-team2-inns2 = [[David Boon]] 184[[Not out|*]] (431) | wickets-team2-inns2 = [[David Capel]] 1/38 (17 overs) | result = Match drawn | venue = [[Sydney Cricket Ground]] | umpires = [[Tony Crafter]] (Aus) and [[Peter McConnell (umpire)|Peter McConnell]] (Aus) | motm = [[David Boon]] (Aus) | report = [http://www.espncricinfo.com/ci/engine/match/63476.html Scorecard] | toss = England won the toss and elected to bat }} ==See also== * [[Bicentenary Celebration match]] ==References== * [[Wisden Cricketers' Almanack]], 1989 edition is the primary source * [http://www.cricketarchive.co.uk/Archive/Scorecards/49/49572.html CricketArchive] has the full scorecard {{Non-Ashes Australia v England Test series}} [[Category:History of Test cricket]] [[Category:International cricket competitions from 1985–86 to 1988]] [[Category:Australian cricket in the 20th century]] [[Category:English cricket in the 20th century]] [[Category:Test cricket matches]] [[Category:1988 in Australian cricket]] [[Category:Australian bicentennial commemorations]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2011}} A '''blue''' is an award earned by athletes at a university and some schools for competition at the highest level. The awarding of blues began at [[University of Oxford|Oxford]] and [[University of Cambridge|Cambridge]] universities in England. It is awarded at [[United Kingdom|British]], and some [[Canada|Canadian]], [[Australia]]n and [[New Zealand]] universities.
==History== The first sporting contest between the universities of Oxford and Cambridge was held on 4 June 1827, when a two-day [[cricket]] match at [[Lord's]], organized by Charles Wordsworth, nephew of the poet [[William Wordsworth|William]], resulted in a draw. There is no record of any university "colours" being worn during the game.<ref name=cam>{{cite web|url=http://www.sport.cam.ac.uk/documents/en/his/history.pdf |title=Blues and the Blues Committee: Some historical notes |publisher=Cambridge University Blues Committee |author=Christopher Thorne |date=10 July 1996 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716024827/http://www.sport.cam.ac.uk/documents/en/his/history.pdf |archivedate=16 July 2011 |df=dmy }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cricketarchive.co.uk/Archive/Scorecards/0/440.html|title=Oxford University v Cambridge University, University Match 1827|publisher=cricketarchive.co.uk|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121020114333/http://www.cricketarchive.co.uk/Archive/Scorecards/0/440.html|archivedate=20 October 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
At the first [[The Boat Race|Boat Race]] in 1829, the Oxford crew was dominated by students of [[Christ Church, Oxford|Christ Church]], whose college colours were dark blue. They wore white shirts with dark blue stripes, while Cambridge wore white with a pink or scarlet sash. At the second race, in 1836, a light blue ribbon was attached to the front of the Cambridge boat, probably as it was the colour of [[Eton College|Eton]]. These colours — light blue for Cambridge, and dark blue for Oxford — became the official colours of the two boat clubs, and through the rivalry of the Boat Race, the colours became inextricably linked with the universities and contests between the two.<ref name=cam/><ref name=oxf>{{cite web |url=http://www.vincents.org/history/theoxfordblue/ |title=The Oxford Blue |author=[[Norris McWhirter]] |publisher=Vincent's Club |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090530175302/http://www.vincents.org/history/theoxfordblue/ |archivedate=30 May 2009 |df=dmy }}</ref>
== University of Cambridge == {{Redirect|Cambridge Blue|the colour itself|Cambridge Blue (colour)|the butterfly with that name|Pseudolycaena marsyas{{!}}''Pseudolycaena marsyas''}} Athletes at the [[University of Cambridge]] may be awarded a '''full blue''' (or simply a '''blue'''), '''half blue''', '''first team colours''' or '''second team colours''' for competing at the highest level of university sport, which must include being in a varsity match or race against the [[University of Oxford]]. A full blue is the highest honour that may be bestowed on a Cambridge athlete, and is a much-coveted and prestigious prize. In general, the full blue standard is approximately that of being successful at a national level of student competition, and the half blue standard is that of being successful at county or regional level.
=== History === Once light blue had been chosen as the colour of Cambridge's Boat Club, the other university sport clubs followed suit, though out of courtesy would request permission from the Boat Club before awarding such a "blue". In the 1860s the three senior sports — rowing, cricket and athletics — were awarding blues, and the presidents of each formed an informal "Blues Committee" to oversee such awards. By 1880 a number of smaller clubs involved in [[varsity match]]es had successfully requested the right to award "half blues".<ref name=cam/>
=== Awarding process === The criteria for awarding blues are different for men and women. Awards are made at the discretion of the men's and women's Blues Committees.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sport.cam.ac.uk/committees/index.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2006-01-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060110021421/http://www.sport.cam.ac.uk/committees/index.html |archivedate=10 January 2006 |df=dmy }}</ref> The Men's Blues Committee is formed from one representative of each of the full blue sports, and the Women's from one representative of each of the full blue and half blue sports. Each committee meets to discuss issues relating to Cambridge sport.
In some sports with full blue status, the varsity match second team is awarded '''second team colours'''.
The awarding of a full blue often requires a person to fulfill a number of requirements in the same academic year, particularly in sports with discretionary full blue status. If, for whatever reason, an exceptional athlete is of or above full blue standard but does not fulfill all the requirements for the 'automatic' award of a full blue in any given year, the committee has the authority to grant an '''extraordinary full blue''' to that person subject to scrutiny of the particular case. The individual's case must be presented to the Blues Committee in person and must be backed up by substantial evidence and references. The award is unlikely to be made unless the person is of world-class or at least international standard.
Each sport has specific criteria for each award; the general categorisation of men's and women's sports is laid out below, though the status of each sport is subject to frequent review.
==== Categorisation of men's sports ==== {| border="1" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="4" width="60%" class="wikitable" |- ! Full Blue |- | [[Boxing]], [[cricket]], [[field hockey]], [[Association football|football]], [[golf]], [[tennis|lawn tennis]], [[table tennis]], [[rowing (sport)|rowing]], [[rugby union]], [[squash (sport)|squash]], [[gymnastics]] |- ! Full Blue (some) / Half Blue (rest) |- | [[Athletics (sport)|Athletics]], [[basketball]], [[cross country running]], [[rugby league]], [[swimming (sport)|swimming]], [[ice hockey]] |- ! Discretionary Full Blue |- | [[Badminton]], [[canoeing]], [[road bicycle racing|cycling]], [[dancesport]], [[fencing]], [[judo]], [[powerlifting]], [[ice hockey]], [[karate]], [[modern pentathlon]], [[orienteering]], [[shooting sports|rifle shooting (small-bore and full-bore)]], [[Sailing#Sailboat racing|sailing]], [[skiing]], [[water polo]], [[real tennis]], [[karting]] |- ! Half Blue |- |[[American football]], [[Archery#Modern competitive archery|archery]], [[Australian rules football]], [[Eton Fives|Eton]] and [[Rugby Fives|Rugby]] [[fives]], [[ice hockey]], [[kickboxing]], [[korfball]], [[lacrosse]], [[lightweight rowing]], [[mountain biking]], [[shooting sports|pistol shooting]], [[polo]], [[rackets (sport)|rackets]], [[association croquet]], [[shooting sports|clay pigeon shooting]], [[Equestrianism|riding]], [[shooting sports|rifle shooting (small-bore and full-bore)]], [[volleyball]], [[windsurfing]], [[yachting]], and mixed lacrosse. |- ! Under review |- | [[Gaelic football]], [[Chess]], [[Tiddlywinks]] |}
==== Categorisation of women's sports ==== {| border="1" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="4" width="60%" class="wikitable" |- ! Full Blue - whole team |- | Boxing, Fencing, football, table tennis, hockey, lacrosse, lawn tennis, [[netball]], rowing, rugby union, squash, dance, St John's College Street Dance Crew |- ! Full Blue (some) / Half Blue (rest) |- | Athletics, cricket, modern pentathlon, swimming, volleyball, basketball, [https://cutkd.soc.srcf.net/ taekwondo] |- ! Discretionary Full Blue |- | Badminton, cross-country, cycling, dancesport, gymnastics, ice hockey, judo, karate, orienteering, rifle shooting (full-bore), sailing, skiing, volleyball, boxing, real tennis |- ! Half Blue |- | Archery, canoeing, [[canoe polo]], cricket, [[Eton fives]], [[gliding]], golf, ice hockey, korfball, lifesaving, lightweight rowing, orienteering, association croquet, pistol shooting, [[polo]], riding, rifle shooting (small-bore), [https://cutkd.soc.srcf.net/ taekwondo], [[trampolining]], [[triathlon]], [[windsurfing]], waterpolo, [[ultimate (sport)|ultimate]] (if they compete in the Open division), yachting, mixed lacrosse |- ! Under review |- | Windsurfing, Tiddlywinks |}
=== Regalia === [[Image:Cambridge-half-blue-blazer.jpg|right|thumb|200px|[[University of Cambridge|Cambridge University]] Half Blue blazer and bow tie.]]
The winner of a blue or half blue is entitled to wear a blues blazer, which is one of the most recognisable and distinctive garments associated with Cambridge University. Full blue blazers are completely coloured [[Cambridge Blue (colour)|Cambridge Blue]]. Half blue blazers have a number of different designs, depending on the wearer's sport; a typical design is an off-white blazer with Cambridge blue lapels and trimmings. There is a variety of other blue and half blue paraphernalia, including scarves, ties, pullovers, bow ties, caps and squares. Such items are worn with pride.
{{As of|2011|5}}, the colour recognised officially by the University as Cambridge Blue actually has a slight green tint.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.cam.ac.uk/system/files/identity_guidelines.pdf |title=Identity guidelines - fifth edition |date=25 March 2012 |publisher=University of Cambridge |accessdate=3 May 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161220071050/https://www.cam.ac.uk/system/files/identity_guidelines.pdf |archivedate=20 December 2016 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
In 2008 in Cambridge an alumna launched Oxbridge Blues Jewellery <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oxbridgebluesjewellery.com/cambridge/|title=Cambridge Blue & Half Blue - Oxbridge Blues Jewellery|website=www.oxbridgebluesjewellery.com|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924062824/http://www.oxbridgebluesjewellery.com/cambridge/|archivedate=24 September 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> specifically for women's blues and half blues at the two Universities. These are the only blues item to have been licensed by the University of Cambridge.
=== Hawks' Club/Ospreys === Men holding blues, half blues or second team colours in a Full blue sport are eligible to join the [[Hawks' Club]]. Women holding any of these awards are eligible to join The Ospreys, which was founded in 1985.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sport.cam.ac.uk/ospreys/about.html |title=About the Ospreys |publisher=Cambridge University Women's Sports Club |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090828063601/http://www.sport.cam.ac.uk/ospreys/about.html |archivedate=28 August 2009 |df=dmy }}</ref>
== University of Oxford == {{Redirect|Oxford Blue|the colour|Oxford Blue (colour)|the cheese variety|Oxford Blue (cheese)}}
===Administration=== At the [[University of Oxford]], the committees for awarding blues and half blues work on much the same principles as the Cambridge committees. The principal difference between the two men's committees is that, at Oxford, all Captains, regardless of their status as full, discretionary, or half blue must attend meetings of the Committee. Until recently, the voting was broken up according to blues status with full blue captains being allowed to vote on all matters while all the other captains could only vote on matters directly relating to half blue sports. In Michaelmas Term 2006, the committee finally allowed discretionary full blue captains the right to vote on matters directly relating to discretionary full blue sports. This has ended many years of inequality for discretionary full blue status captains and was largely welcomed by the committee.
The committees are administered by an elected president, secretary and treasurer who serve one year. Unlike at Cambridge, where the president of Cambridge University Boat Club holds the position, at Oxford, any captain can be elected president, regardless of sport or status.
The role of the president is to call and serve as chair of any meeting of the committee, of which there are normally 3 per year (6 for the women). They also serve as the representative of the committee and sit on the University Sports Strategy Committee and the Executive Committee of the Sports Federation. Both Presidents along with the Director of Sport represent Oxford at any meetings of a Joint Blues Committee held with Cambridge. The purpose of the Joint Blues Committee is to discuss issues of eligibility for the varsity match and to settle any disputes between the sporting communities of the two universities.
[[Image:Oxford-half-blue-blazer.jpg|right|thumb|200px|[[University of Oxford|Oxford University]] Rifle Club half blue blazer and tie]]
===Costume=== The colour of an Oxford full blue blazer is dark blue. The Oxford half blue blazer can be one of two designs. Either it is composed of thick vertical stripes of dark blue and off-white, as in the adjacent image, or it can be dark blue, as the full blue blazer, with two white stripes above the club badge on the left breast.
The Oxford range of Oxbridge Blues Jewellery<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oxbridgebluesjewellery.com/oxford/|title=Oxford Blue and Half Blue - Oxbridge Blues Jewellery|website=www.oxbridgebluesjewellery.com|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924062825/http://www.oxbridgebluesjewellery.com/oxford/|archivedate=24 September 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> was launched in Oxford at the Women's Blues Award Ceremony in the Natural History Museum in 2012. The range is the same as the Cambridge design except that the semi-precious stones are navy blue and white.
===Clubs=== The club associated with the Oxford blue is [[Vincent’s Club]], although its membership is not restricted to blues, and there are wider criteria for election. ''[[Atalantas]]'' is a club for sportswomen at Oxford, and also is not restricted to blues.
== 'Blues' in Australia ==
=== University of Adelaide === The [[Sport at the University of Adelaide|Adelaide University Sports Association]] at the [[University of Adelaide]] in [[Adelaide]], [[South Australia]] awards a blue and a half blue for outstanding sporting achievement, and a club letters for both sporting achievement and service.<ref>{{cite web|title=AWARDS |url=http://unione.theblacks.com.au/Common/ContentWM.aspx?CID=13 |publisher=The Adelaide University Sports Association |accessdate=10 February 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130409084809/http://unione.theblacks.com.au/Common/ContentWM.aspx?CID=13 |archivedate=9 April 2013 |df=dmy }}</ref>
=== La Trobe University === [[La Trobe University]] has awarded blues and half blues since its early years, with the first blues being awarded in 1968. The annual Blues and Sports Awards Night recognises the elite sports men and women who have represented La Trobe via the university's clubs, intervarsity sporting competitions and the World University games. There are also awards for Outstanding Service which recognise the outstanding service to sports clubs by members of the La Trobe Community.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.latrobe.edu.au/unisport/clubs/honour-board|title=Life Members and Honour Board|last=University|first=La Trobe|website=www.latrobe.edu.au|access-date=2016-04-12|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160422001250/http://www.latrobe.edu.au/unisport/clubs/honour-board|archivedate=22 April 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
=== University of Melbourne === The Melbourne University Sports Association (originally known as the 'Sports Union') awards blues and half blues at the [[University of Melbourne]], for outstanding performance in inter-university events (primarily through the [[Australian University Games]] and Australian University Championships). A 'distinguished service award' may be made (including to non-students) for outstanding service to a sporting club (or clubs), the Sports Association, and/or sport at the university generally.
Blues were first awarded in 1904, as one of the first items of business of the newly formed Sports Union, with retrospective awards made back as early as 1870. Initially, awards were made automatically to all participants in an intervarsity contest, with the level (full or half blue) dependant on the sport. In 1911, this model was replaced with the formation of a 'Blues Advisory Board' to determine the awards based on an individual's performance. The BAB continues to serve this role today.<ref>{{cite book | last = Senyard | first = June E. | year = 2004 | title = The Ties That Bind: A History of Sport at the University of Melbourne | publisher = Walla Walla Press | location = Petersham, NSW}}</ref>
=== University of Queensland === Blues and half-blues have been awarded at the University of Queensland since 1912. Blues have been awarded for outstanding performances in club fixtures, representative games, and inter-university competitions as well as for international representation whilst studying at the University. The University of Queensland blue is the highest sporting accolade an athlete can receive from the university. In recent years, UQ Sport through its Blues Advisory Committee, has developed a selection method and criteria to ensure that blues and half blues at the university are of the highest standard. Each year these awards are presented at the UQ Sport Blues Awards Dinner.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uqsport.com.au/content/uq-blues-awards|title=UQ BLUES AWARDS|publisher=University of Queensland|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151022192217/http://www.uqsport.com.au/content/uq-blues-awards|archivedate=22 October 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
== 'Blues' in New Zealand == Since 1919 the New Zealand Universities Blue has been awarded to [[NZ University]] students who have achieved excellence both on and off the field of play. Currently [[University Sport New Zealand]] is responsible for presenting this award<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.universitysport.org.nz/nzu-blues|title=NZU Blues - Student Life & Sport|publisher=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130528015531/http://www.universitysport.org.nz/nzu-blues|archivedate=28 May 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
In addition, individual universities will award their own blues. For example, [[University of Otago]] blues date from 1907,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ousa.org.nz/recreation/blues-and-golds-awards/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-05-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130522130102/http://www.ousa.org.nz/recreation/blues-and-golds-awards/ |archivedate=22 May 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> therefore pre-dating the New Zealand Universities blue.
== See also == *[[Hawks' Club]] – social club for men holding a Cambridge full blue, Half blue or second team colours *[[Rugby League Varsity Match]] – annual rugby league match between Oxford and Cambridge *[[The Boat Race]] *[[The Women's Boat Race]] *[[The Colours Match]] – annual rugby union match between [[University College Dublin R.F.C.|University College Dublin]] and [[Dublin University Football Club|Trinity College, Dublin]] *[[University Golf Match|The University Golf Match]] – annual golf match between Oxford and [[Cambridge University Golf Club|Cambridge]] *[[The University Match (cricket)|The University Match]] – annual cricket match between [[Oxford University Cricket Club|Oxford]] and [[Cambridge University Cricket Club|Cambridge]] *[[The Varsity Match]] – annual rugby union match between [[Oxford University RFC|Oxford]] and [[Cambridge University R.U.F.C.|Cambridge]] *[[The Varsity Polo Match]] - annual polo match between [[Oxford University Polo Club|Oxford]] and [[Cambridge University Polo Club|Cambridge]] *[[University Match (hockey)|The Varsity Match (hockey)]] - annual hockey match between Oxford and Cambridge *[[Varsity letter]] – similar award granted by schools in the United States *[[Vincent's Club]] – social club for men consisting of those of appropriate character at the University of Oxford. Many are sportsmen. *[[Sporting colours]]

{{Infobox golf facility | name = Circling Raven Golf Club | image = | imagesize = | caption = | location = near [[Worley, Idaho]] | coordinates = {{coord|47.424|-116.964|region:US_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | pushpin_map = USA Idaho#USA | pushpin_relief = 1 | establishment = 2003, {{Time ago|2003}} | type = Resort / Public | owner = [[Coeur d'Alene people|Coeur d'Alene Tribe]] | operator = Coeur d'Alene Tribe | elevation = {{convert|2600|ft|-1}} | holes = 18 | tournaments = <!-- regular tournaments held if any--> | greens = [[Agrostis|Bentgrass]] | fairways = [[Poa pratensis|Bluegrass]] | website = {{URL|http://www.cdacasino.com/golf/}} | course1 = <!-- individual course name, can leave blank if same as article title--> | designer1 = Gene Bates | par1 = 72 | length1 = {{convert|7189|yd|abbr=on}}<ref name=scorecd>{{cite web|url=http://www.cdacasino.com/assets/golf/CRG_s040112_ScoreCRD2012.pdf |publisher=Circling Raven Golf Club |title=Scorecard |accessdate=July 1, 2016}}</ref> | rating1 = 74.0 | slope1 = 144<ref name=crslope>{{cite web|url=https://ncrdb.usga.org/NCRDB/courseTeeInfo.aspx?CourseID=3840 |publisher=USGA |title=Course Rating and Slope Database™ - Circling Raven Golf Club|accessdate=July 1, 2016}}</ref> | record1 = | course2 = <!-- if only one course: leave this entry and all below parts blank --> | designer2 = | par2 = | length2 = | rating2 = | slope2 = | record2 = | image2 = | imagesize2 = | caption2 = }}
'''Circling Raven Golf Club''' is an 18-hole championship [[golf course]] in the [[Pacific Northwest|northwest]] [[United States]], located in [[Idaho Panhandle|northern]] [[Idaho]] near [[Worley, Idaho|Worley]]. It was rated the third best public course in Idaho by ''[[Golf Digest]]'' in August 2015.<ref name=glfgig15>{{cite news |url=http://www.golfdigest.com/story/idaho-best-in-state-rankings |magazine=Golf Digest |title=The Best Golf Courses in Idaho |date=August 24, 2015 |accessdate=July 1, 2016}}</ref>
Owned and operated by the [[Coeur d'Alene people|Coeur d'Alene Tribe]], Circling Raven opened for play {{Time ago|2003|spellout=yes}} in the summer of 2003.<ref name=upscalmko>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=M2ZWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=q_IDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2385%2C675637 |newspaper=Spokesman-Review |location=Spokane, Washington |last=Bergum |first=Steve |title=North Idaho golf scene gets upscale makeover|date=April 12, 2003|page=C1 }}</ref><ref name=asrewn>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=fmdWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=v_IDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2587%2C6929123 |newspaper=Spokesman-Review |location=Spokane, Washington |last=Bergum |first=Steve |title=A sure winner |date=June 7, 2003 |page=6, Golf }}</ref><ref name=tiout>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=4WhWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=vfIDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3104%2C7613775 |newspaper=Spokesman-Review |location=Spokane, Washington |agency=(photo)|title=Trying it out|date=July 31, 2003 |page=C1}}</ref><ref name=sdirn>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=4WhWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=vfIDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5628%2C7984300|newspaper=Spokesman-Review |location=Spokane, Washington |agency=(photo)|title=Seeking direction |date=July 31, 2003 |page=B1}}</ref> It was preceded on the site by a casino (1993) and hotel (2001).<ref name=crppoh>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=xY9XAAAAIBAJ&sjid=g_IDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3174%2C3194683 |newspaper=Spokesman-Review |location=Spokane, Washington |last=Kramer |first=Becky |title=Casino's resort plans put on hold |date=December 15, 2001 |page=A14 }}</ref> The course is named after a visionary chief of the tribe in the [[18th century]].<ref name=chkdi>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=4ChYAAAAIBAJ&sjid=IfcDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5719%2C5218944 |newspaper=Spokane Daily Chronicle |location=Washington |agency=(photo)|title=Chief's kin dies |date=April 20, 1960|page=b3 }}</ref><ref name=flagnpgnt>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=VJlRAAAAIBAJ&sjid=XQgEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6908%2C6846997 |newspaper=Spokesman-Review |location=Spokane, Washington |last=Taggart |first=Cynthia |title=Circling Raven will fly again in pageant |date=July 30, 1990 |page=A9}}</ref><ref name=lcmncly>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=b2ZWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=LvMDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2012%2C1532129 |newspaper=Spokesman-Review |location=Spokane, Washington |last=Bergum |first=Steve |title=Loop courses maturing nicely |date=June 3, 2006 |page=3, Golf }}</ref>
Designed by [[Florida]]-based architect Gene Bates,<ref name=asrewn/> the back tees at Circling Raven are at {{convert|7189|yd}};<ref name=scorecd/> the [[Handicap (golf)#Course rating and slope|course rating]] is 74.0 with a [[slope rating]] of 144.<ref name=crslope/> The terrain varies between rolling prairie, woodlands, and wetlands at an average [[elevation]] of approximately {{convert|2600|ft|-1}} above [[sea level]]. The course is spread out over more than {{convert|600|acres|km2}} and the practice facility covers {{convert|25|acre}}.<ref name=lcmncly/>
==Events== In September 2005, Circling Raven hosted a team from [[Royal Dornoch Golf Club]] in [[Scotland]] for a friendly international competition and cultural exchange.<ref name=stmcrpg>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=kmhWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=-vIDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6337%2C2285936|newspaper=Spokesman-Review |location=Spokane, Washington |last=Bergum |first=Steve |title=Scottish team, Circling Raven plan gathering|date=May 14, 2005|page=C1}}</ref><ref name=shasmtrcs>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=RGdWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=FvMDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5690%2C10700008 |newspaper=Spokesman-Review |location=Spokane, Washington |last=Bergum |first=Steve |title=Sharing as a matter of course |date=September 20, 2005|page=B1}}</ref> The following August, the course was the site of the [[Pacific Northwest PGA Championship|Pacific Northwest PGA Professional Championship]], won by Ryan Malby.<ref name=malbyhts>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=WhdZAAAAIBAJ&sjid=PPMDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5658%2C1756298 |newspaper=Spokesman-Review |location=Spokane, Washington |last=Bergum |first=Steve |title=Malby heats up with 68 to take title|date=August 25, 2006|page=C3}}</ref> The event returned six years later in 2012, and was won by Ryan Benzel, a former [[Idaho Vandals|Idaho Vandal]].<ref name=bw3wpocr>{{cite news |url=http://www.spokesman.com/stories/2012/sep/20/benzel-wins-three-way-playoff-circling-raven/ |newspaper=Spokesman-Review |location=Spokane, Washington |last=Meehan |first=Jim |title=Benzel wins three-way playoff at Circling Raven |date=September 20, 2012 |accessdate=July 2, 2016}}</ref>
==Location== The resort complex is just east of the intersection of [[U.S. Route 95 in Idaho|U.S. Route 95]] and [[Idaho State Highway 58|State Highway 58]] in southwestern [[Kootenai County, Idaho|Kootenai County]], about {{convert|3|mi|0|spell=in}} northwest of Worley and {{convert|30|mi|-1|spell=in}} south of the city of [[Coeur d'Alene, Idaho|Coeur d'Alene]]. The southern end of [[Lake Coeur d'Alene]] and [[Heyburn State Park]] are approximately {{convert|10|mi|km|spell=in}} southeast, [[As the crow flies|as the raven flies]]. The nearest major airport is [[Spokane International Airport|Spokane International]], about {{convert|45|mi|-1}} northwest by vehicle.
==Scorecard== {{Golf18|title=Circling Raven Golf Club}} {{par18|5|4|3|4|5|4|3|4|4|36|4|4|5|3|4|4|3|5|4|36|72 }} {{handicap18|name=Men's |7|11|15|1|5|13|17|9|3|14|6|2|12|18|8|16|4|10}} {{gold18|74.0 / 144 |513|395|217|406|574|387|212|386|474|3564|336|446|581|253|397|426|192|559|435|3625|7189}} {{blue18|71.6 / 137 |493|349|186|380|529|351|185|357|451|3281|321|418|535|218|328|391|176|519|392|3298|6578}} {{white18 |rssize=9pt |M:69.2/131 W:75.1/138 |483|310|182|360|501|317|154|329|437|3073|298|379|488|200|306|369|162|486|347|3035|6108}} {{par18|5|4|3|4|5|4|3|4|4|36|4|4|5|3|4|4|3|5|4|36|72 }} {{handicap18|name=Women's|7|13|15|5|1|11|17|9|3| 14|6|2|12|18|8|16|4|10}} {{red18 |70.4 / 128 |466|275|163|268|405|272|149|298|397|2693|269|347|436|145|269|348|137|431|314|2696|5389}} {{green18 |66.0 / 116 |369|260|142|253|392|219|131|276|359|2401|174|323|391|135|240|267|103|400|274|2307|4708}} {{end18}} {{small|Source:}}<ref name=scorecd/><ref name=crslope/>

{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Estadio Defensores del Chaco | image = [[File:Platea VIP Defensores.jpg|center|400px]] | caption = The stadium in 2016 following renovation | location = [[Asunción]], [[Paraguay]] | opened = 1917{{cite web|url=http://www.worldstadiums.com/south_america/countries/paraguay.shtml|title=World Stadiums - Stadiums in Paraguay|website=www.worldstadiums.com|accessdate=23 September 2018}} | renovated = 2000, 2015 | owner = [[Paraguayan Football Association]] | surface = Grass | seating_capacity = 42,354 (seated) | tenants = [[Paraguay national football team]]
[[Nacional Asunción]]
[[Club Guaraní|Guaraní]]
[[Olimpia Asunción]] (1917–present) }} '''Estadio Defensores del Chaco''' is a [[multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Asunción]], [[Paraguay]]. It is currently used mostly for [[football (soccer)|football]] matches. The stadium once had a 50,000+ capacity, however over the years the stadium has undergone remodeling, dropping the capacity to 42,354. The stadium was again renovated in 2015.[http://www.5dias.com.py/40331-estiman-que-obra-del-defensores-superara-los-us-2-5-millones ]{{dead link|date=September 2018}} ==Overview== The stadium was opened in 1917 and its first name was "Estadio de Puerto Sajonia" because it was located in the [[Sajonia (Asunción)|Sajonia]] neighbourhood in Asunción. After Uruguay won the Olympic gold medal in football in [[Football at the 1924 Summer Olympics|1924]], the Paraguayan Football Association decided to rename the stadium "Uruguay" to honor the South American Nation. Later, the name was reverted to Estadio Puerto Sajonia. During the [[Chaco War]], the stadium was used as a munitions depot and troop meeting arena. After the war, it was renamed with the current name "Defensores del Chaco" (Defenders of the Chaco) in honour of the triumphant soldiers that took part in the [[Chaco War]] between [[Paraguay]] and [[Bolivia]]. It underwent renovations during 1939, 1996 and 2007.[http://apf.cerocinco.net/insta_defensores.php Asociación Paraguaya de Fútbol] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080107073220/http://apf.cerocinco.net/insta_defensores.php |date=2008-01-07 }} The stadium is not owned by a team (it is a [[List of national stadiums|national stadium]]) and it is used primarily to host the home games of the [[Paraguay national football team]] and for international football club tournament games such as the [[Copa Libertadores]] and the [[Copa Sudamericana]]. It also held important matches during the 1999 [[Copa América]], including the final in which [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]] defeated [[Uruguay national football team|Uruguay]]. ==Tenants== The [[Paraguay national football team]] plays their home fixtures at the stadium during FIFA World Cup qualifiers and international friendlies. Local clubs such as [[Club Olimpia]], [[Club Nacional]] and [[Club Guaraní]] often play their home games at the stadium for [[Primera División Paraguaya]], [[Copa Libertadores]] and [[Copa Sudamericana]] fixtures. ==Accidents and incidents== *1 February 2009; two anti-riot police officers were killed and five injured when they were struck by a [[cement]] block that was part of the stadium. The cement block fell from a height of seven meters. The football match taking place during the collapse was delayed 40 minutes.{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2009/WORLD/americas/02/02/paraguay.stadium/index.html|title=Two police killed in Paraguay stadium collapse - CNN.com|website=www.cnn.com|accessdate=23 September 2018}} ==Other events== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Country ||Artist|| Date ||Tour |- |{{flagicon|Sweden}}||[[Roxette]]||23 April 1992||[[Join the Joyride! Tour]] |- |{{flagicon|Mexico}}||[[Luis Miguel]]||3 December 1996||[[Tour America 1996]] |- |{{flagicon|Mexico}}||[[RBD]]||25 April 2008||[[Empezar desde Cero Tour 2008]] |- |{{flagicon|France}} {{flagicon|Spain}}

{{Football club infobox | clubname = Zhashtyk Osh| image = | fullname = FC Zhashtyk Osh| nickname = | founded = | ground = [[Suyumbayev Stadion]]
[[Osh, Kyrgyzstan|Osh]], [[Kyrgyzstan]]| capacity = 12,000| chairman = | manager = | league = [[Kyrgyzstan League]] | season = 1997| position = 8th| }} '''FC Zhashtyk Osh''' is a [[Kyrgyzstan]]i football club based in [[Osh, Kyrgyzstan|Osh]], [[Kyrgyzstan]] that plays in the top division in Kyrgyzstan, the [[Kyrgyzstan League]]. The club plays its home games at [[Suyumbayev Stadion]]. In 1998 [[FC Zhashtyk-Ak-Altyn Kara-Suu]] was founded after the merger of the teams Zhashtyk Osh and [[FC Ak-Altyn Kara-Suu]]. == External links == *[http://www.klisf.info/numeric/index.app?cmd=comm_tst&lang=ru&id=987698240417616855569560804412 Career stats by KLISF] {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Zhashtyk Osh}} [[Category:Football clubs in Kyrgyzstan]] [[Category:Osh]] {{Kyrgyzstan-footyclub-stub}}
