{{other uses|La Bombonera (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox stadium |name=Estadio Alberto J. Armando |nickname= ''La Bombonera'' |image=[[File:La Bombonera. - panoramio.jpg|250px]] |fullname= Estadio Alberto J. Armando |location= Brandsen 805 CP 1161
[[La Boca]], [[Buenos Aires]] |broke_ground= 18 February 1938 |built= 1938–40 |opened= {{Start date and years ago|df=yes|1940|05|25}} |renovated= 1995–96 |expanded= |closed= |demolished= |owner= [[Boca Juniors]] |operator= |surface= Grass |construction_cost= |architect= José Luis Delpini, [[Viktor Sulčič]], Raúl Bes |structural engineer= |former_names= {{collapsible list| * Estadio Boca Juniors (1940–86) * Estadio Camilo Cichero (1986–2000) }} |tenants= {{infobox stadium/tenantlist |tenant_clubs= [[Boca Juniors]] |tenant_years= 1940–present}} |seating_capacity= 49,000{{cite web|url=http://www.bocajuniors.com.ar/el-club/la-bombonera |title=La Bombonera {{!}} El club |work=bocajuniors.com.ar |publisher=CA Boca Juniors |accessdate=10 June 2018 |language=es}} | record_attendance = {{formatnum: 57395}} ([[Boca Juniors|Boca]]–[[San Lorenzo de Almagro|San Lorenzo]], 25 May 1940){{cite web|url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/1593822-ranking-the-top-10-most-iconic-stadiums-in-world-football/page/2 |title=Ranking the Top 10 Most Iconic Stadiums in World Football |date=12 April 2013}} |dimensions= 105 x 68 m }} The '''Estadio Alberto J. Armando''' (formerly the "Estadio Camilo Cichero") is an [[association football]] [[stadium]] located in [[La Boca]] district of [[Buenos Aires]]. Widely known as '''''La Bombonera''''' ({{IPA-es|la βomboˈneɾa}}; {{lang-en|The chocolate box}}{{cite web|url=http://www.theage.com.au/travel/blogs/the-backpacker/want-to-get-to-know-a-country-head-for-the-stadium-20100920-15j2h.html|title=Want to get to know a country? Head for the stadium|last=Ben Groundwater|date=20 September 2010|work=The Age|publisher=Fairfax Media|accessdate=26 April 2013}}) due to its shape, with a "flat" stand on one side of the pitch and three steep stands round the rest of the stadium.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/bbcthree/article/5957cb44-65fe-43d2-bbf5-48e336f48b23 |title=Some of the world's scariest places to play or watch football |work=BBC News |accessdate=11 November 2018}} It has a capacity of 49,000. The stadium is owned by [[Boca Juniors]], one of [[Argentina]]'s top [[Association football|football]] clubs. The unusual shape of the stadium has led to it having excellent acoustics and the Boca support being nicknamed "La Doce ([[12th man (football)|The 12th man]]"). The pitch at La Bombonera is the minimum size required under [[FIFA]] regulations - 105m x 68m. The stadium is widely regarded as one of the most emblematic stadiums of the world,[http://bleacherreport.com/articles/1060108-50-sports-venues-to-visit-before-you-die/page/5 50 Sports Venues to Visit Before You Die], Bleacher Report, 26 Sep 2012[http://www.lanacion.com.ar/nota.asp?nota_id=592693 Boca v. River, un espectáculo internacional], ''La Nación'' 15 Apr 2004[https://web.archive.org/web/20150402112020/http://www.pagina12.com.ar/diario/deportes/8-120059.html «La Bombonera» inspira temor], ''Página/12''[http://www.marca.com/2014/11/30/futbol/futbol_internacional/argentina/1417382527.html Un día en el fútbol argentino], Diario Marca[http://www.marca.com/2014/09/09/futbol/futbol_internacional/argentina/1410214277.html Marca y un día con la Doce][http://www.infobae.com/2014/03/28/1553461-la-mitica-bombonera-como-nunca-antes-la-habias-visto La mítica Bombonera, como nunca antes la habías visto][http://www.diarioveloz.com/notas/3564-espana-se-rindio-los-pies-la-bombonera España, rendida a los pies de La Bombonera][http://www.ligabbva.com/2544_liga-bbva/2712638_asi-es-la-bombonera-el-mitico-campo-de-boca-juniors.html Así es La Bombonera, Liga BBVA][http://www.ole.com.ar/boca-juniors/Estadio-copero_0_1318668386.html Estadio copero, una fortaleza][http://www.ole.com.ar/futbol-internacional/Vuelta-Boca_0_1327067550.html Vuelta por la Boca], ''Olé'', 26 Mar 2015 and has been declared of public interest by the Government of Buenos Aires autonomous city.[http://www.parlamentario.com/noticia-74878.html "La Bombonera" fue declarada de interés deportivo, turístico y cultural de la Ciudad], Parlamentario.com The stadium, as well as being the home of Boca Juniors, who have over 16 million fans (the highest in Argentina),http://theworldgame.sbs.com.au/article/2008/02/27/brazils-flamengo-has-most-fans-world is also used as a concert venue. Past performers at ''La Bombonera'' have included [[Lenny Kravitz]], [[Elton John]], [[James Blunt]], the [[Bee Gees]], and the [[Backstreet Boys]].{{cn|date=October 2017}} ==History== ===Background=== [[File:Estadio_Boca_Juniors_1929.jpg|thumb|left|200px|The old Boca Juniors stadium in Brandsen and Del Crucero, where Boca Juniors played from 1924 to 1938.]] Previous to ''La Bombonera'', Boca Juniors had used several locations before settling on their current ground on Brandsen. Club's first ground had been located in ''Dársena Sur''[https://books.google.com/books?id=KxBNr-TWTZ0C&pg=PA39&lpg=PA39&dq=boca+juniors+darsena+sur&source=bl&ots=H4VPZ8fTBc&sig=tNUU7S3kdtAO9gE3LxmcEvfk4Yo&hl=en&sa=X&ei=lp2iVIjzC87wggThzoOABw&ved=0CCQQ6AEwATgK#v=onepage&q=boca%20juniors%20darsena%20sur&f=false ''Cien años de multitud: El período amateur (1905–1930)'' by Horacio D. Rosatti – Ed. Galerna, 2008] – {{ISBN|9789505565405}} of the old Buenos Aires port (currently [[Puerto Madero]]) and ''Isla Demarchi''[http://blogs.lanacion.com.ar/historia-argentina/personalidades/breve-historia-de-la-isla-demarchi/ "Breve historia de la isla Demarchi" on ''La Nación''], 30 Ago 2012{{cite web |url=http://www.lapasiondeboca.com/la-bombonera-la-cancha-de-boca |title=La Pasion Boca-Boca and their stadiums |language=Spanish |publisher=Lapasiondeboca.com |accessdate=5 May 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120305104937/http://www.lapasiondeboca.com/la-bombonera-la-cancha-de-boca |archivedate=5 March 2012 |df= }} before moving to Brandsen and Del Crucero (currently Del Valle Iberlucea) streets in 1924. The club built a stadium there.[http://www.planetabocajuniors.com.ar/institucion/estadio/ "La Bombonera" on Planeta Boca Juniors] This would be used as home venue until the construction of ''La Bombonera'' on the same location. In [[1931 in Argentine football|1931]], the Boca Juniors' steering committee (led by president Ruperto Molfino) acquired the lands to the Municipality of Buenos Aires for [[Argentine Peso|A$]] 2,200,000. Three years later the club published a call for tenders to built its new stadium.[http://biblioteca.afa.org.ar/libros/libro_52/ Memoria y balance de la AFA 1934 - Pág. 101] The project was finally granted to the Delpini-Sulcic-Bes architectural office.[http://www.pagina12.com.ar/diario/sociedad/3-143667-2010-04-11.html El arquitecto olvidado], ''Página/12'', 11 Apr 2010 which would be also design the [[Abasto Shopping]] in the 1990s. The old stadium (still with wooden grandstands) was used for the last time on April 10, 1938, then being demolished to build the new stadium on the same location. While ''La Bombonera'' was under construction, Boca Juniors played their home games at [[Estadio Arquitecto Ricardo Etcheverri|Ferro Carril Oeste stadium]]. === Opening and later refurbishments === [[File:La_Bombonera_en_construcci%C3%B3n.jpg|thumb|left|200px|The stadium under construction.]] The stadium finally opened on May 25, 1940, with a [[Exhibition game|friendly match]] between Boca and [[Club Atlético San Lorenzo de Almagro|San Lorenzo]], which the home side won 2-0 with both goals scored by [[:es:Ricardo Alarc%C3%B3n (futbolista)|Ricardo Alarcón]]. Due to the fact that the stadium did not have a [[lighting]] system, the game only lasted 70' (two halves of 35' each). The first official game at the new stadium was on June 2, [[1940 Argentine Primera División|1940]], when Boca Juniors beat [[Newell's Old Boys]] by 2–0. Ricardo Alarcón (who had scored in the opening game v. San Lorenzo) scored the first official goal in the new venue.[http://www.historiadeboca.com.ar/partido.asp?tfAnioPartido=1940&tfTipoTorneo=7&CodigoPartido=319|título=Boca Juniors 2 - Newell's 0] on Historia de Boca [[File:Placa sanlorenzo boca.jpg|thumb|right|200px| Placque donated by San Lorenzo de Almagro on the occasion of the inauguration of ''La Bombonera'', May 1940.]] After the stadium was inaugurated, the club continued to introduce refurbishments to expand its capacity. As a result, on November 16, 1941, a second tier was opened on the north side of the stadium, near Casa Amarilla train station. The grandstand was named "[[Natalio Pescia]]" in honour of one of the key players in Boca Juniors' history.[http://www.museoboquense.com/recuerdos_ver.php?id=000000055 El León de la defensa] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090216134622/http://museoboquense.com/recuerdos_ver.php?id=000000055 |date=2009-02-16 }} on Museo Boquense In 1949 the club decided to add a third tier, adding also a lighting system. All of those works were completed in 1953;{{cite web|url=http://www.bocajuniors.com.ar/english/elclub_bombonera.php|title=The Stadium|publisher=[[Club Atlético Boca Juniors]]|accessdate=2008-11-07 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080704130830/http://www.bocajuniors.com.ar/english/elclub_bombonera.php |archivedate=2008-07-04}} this third tier gave the stadium its enduring nickname: ''La Bombonera''.{{cite web|url=http://www.midfielddynamo.com/stadia/intimidating.htm|title=10 Intimidating Stadiums (Worldwide)|publisher=mifielddynamo.com|accessdate=2008-11-07}} Boca Juniors celebrated with a friendly match v. [[Croatia]]n club [[HNK Hajduk Split]], which ended 1–1.[http://www.historiadeboca.com.ar/partido.asp?tfAnioPartido=1953&tfTipoTorneo=2024&CodigoPartido=4096 Boca Juniors 1 - Hajduk Split (cro.)] on Historia de Boca [[File:La Bombonera.jpg|thumb|left|200px|''La Bombonera'' during a night game v. [[Colo Colo]], with the refurbished boxes at right, March 2008.]] The stadium was named on April 20, 1986, by team President [[Antonio Alegre]] in honor of Camilo Cichero, a former team president under whose tenure work on ''La Bombonera'' began. It was renamed on December 27, 2000, by team President [[Mauricio Macri]] in honor of [[Alberto Armando]], team president during its resurgence during the 1960s as well as a former business partner of his father [[Francisco Macri]]. The stadium was expanded and modernized during Macri's tenure, notably with the addition in 1996 of a fourth tier; and a wing housing a press area, VIP boxes, a museum, and offices. The stadium's exterior was later decorated with works by painters [[Rómulo Macció]] and [[Pérez Celis]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.bocajuniors.com.ar/la-bombonera/historia |title=Boca Juniors y sus estadios |work=Club Atlético Boca Juniors |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130318072252/http://www.bocajuniors.com.ar/la-bombonera/historia |archivedate=2013-03-18 |df= }} Since then, ''La Bombonera'' was not remodeled until 1996 when the presidency of [[Mauricio Macri]] decided to expand its capacity to 57,500 spectators. Works included the demolition of the lateral boxes on Del Valle Iberlucea street, replacing them by a small stand and new and modern boxes (with metallic structure) placed over there. The "new" Bombonera was reinaugurated with a friendly match v. [[Club Universidad de Chile]] won by Boca Juniors by 3–1.[http://www.historiadeboca.com.ar/partido.asp?tfAnioPartido=1996&tfTipoTorneo=2996&CodigoPartido=3589 Boca Juniors 3 –– Universidad (Chi) 1] An electronic screen was installed in 2008,[http://edant.ole.com.ar/notas/2008/01/29/01595690.html Lo miran por TV] by Horacio García on ''Olé'', 21 Jan 2008 therefore Boca Juniors stadium became the third venue with this technology after Vélez Sársfield and River Plate. At the beginning of 2012, more than 500 seats were replaced and other 500 were added, apart of building four additional boxes. ==Origin of the name== The stadium is popularly known as ''La Bombonera''. It is said that the nickname came along the project of [[Viktor Sulčič]] during the process of development. On occasion of Sulčič's birthday, a friend gave him a box of chocolates as a gift. After that, Sulčič used to go with the box at meetings with engineer Delpine and other persons that collaborated with the project to show them that the box shape was very like the one of the stadium they were designing. Since then, the stadium would be known as ''La Bombonera'' ("box of chocolates" in [[Spanish language|Spanish]]) and that name has remained to present days. In fact, the opening day (May 25, 1940) the stadium was named that way even by the club executives.[https://www.pagina12.com.ar/diario/sociedad/subnotas/143667-46175-2010-04-11.html Una caja de bombones de regalo], ''Página/12'', 26 Apr 2010 Nevertheless, there are other stories or myths about the origin of the nickname. One of them tells that Delpini projected the stands with a highly vertical grade of inclination to host 100,000 persons (which was the first project). The shape of the stands looked like the carts used to collect horses dung in the streets of Buenos Aires. Other version credits journalist Hugo Marini or broadcaster Joaquín Carballo Serantes (aka) "Fioravanti" for the ''Bombonera'' nickname.''La vida color de Boca, 100 años de una pasión argentina'', vol. 1, [http://www.lanacion.com.ar/691785-la-vida-color-de-boca published by ''La Nación''], March 2005 Despite its distinguished nickname, the first official denomination came on April 20, 1986, when it was named "Camilo Cichero" in commemoration of the president under whose tenure the stadium was projected and built.[http://conexion2000.com.ar/bomboneraabbatangelo.htm LA BOMBONERA. UNA HISTORIA DE IDENTIDAD Y MISTICA] by Arq. Pablo F. Abbátangelo on Conexion2000.com.ar That same day Boca Juniors defeated [[Talleres de Córdoba]] by 4–2. Nevertheless, president Mauricio Macri decided to change the stadium's name to "[[Alberto Armando|Alberto J. Armando]]", honoring long-time president of the club during two periods (1954–55, 1960–80).[http://www.infobae.com/2015/11/23/1771739-los-momentos-mauricio-macri-boca-que-marcaron-su-perfil-politico/ Los momentos de Mauricio Macri en Boca que marcaron su perfil político], Infobae.com, 23 Nov 2015 ==Facilities== {{Panorama |image = File:Panorama La Bombonera (Buenos Aires, Argentina) looking east.jpg |height = 200 |alt = |caption = Panoramic view of Estadio Alberto J. Armando, mostly known as ''La Bombonera'', taken in 2012. }} La Bombonera currently has a capacity of around 48,000 and the club's popularity make tickets hard to find, especially for the [[Superclásico]] [[Local derby|derby]] against [[Club Atlético River Plate|River Plate]].{{cite web|url=http://travel.independent.co.uk/americas/article2187963.ece|title=Buenos Aires: In a liga of its own|date=27 January 2007|publisher=[[The Independent]]|accessdate=2008-11-07|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080118151545/http://travel.independent.co.uk/americas/article2187963.ece |archivedate=2008-01-18}} Out of its capacity of 49,000, there are 37,538 seats, 2780 are boxes and 8,682 standing. Both its interior and exterior are lined with a number of [[mural]]s painted by the artist [[Pérez Celis]] depicting many of the club's legendary players and aspects of the district's culture, such as the life of Italian immigrants.{{cite web|url=http://www.bocampeonweb.com.ar/english/bombonera2.htm|title=Fochada de la Bombonera|publisher=Bocacampeonweb|accessdate=2008-11-08}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}} In 1996 a small stand was built on the 4th side, which had been largely open until then, except for some VIP boxes.{{cite web|url=http://www.stadiumguide.com/bombonera/|title=La Bombonera|publisher=The Stadium Guide|accessdate=22 March 2013}} [[Diego Maradona]], who played for and supports Boca Juniors, has his own executive box at the stadium. There are three parking lots at the stadium for members.{{cite web|url=http://www.agrupacionnuevoboca.com.ar/Club/Estadio/Default.asp|title=El Estadio: Alberto J. Armando|publisher=Agrupación Nuevo Boca|language=Spanish|accessdate=29 January 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130218135829/http://www.agrupacionnuevoboca.com.ar/Club/Estadio/Default.asp|archivedate=18 February 2013|df=}} ==Argentina national team on La Bombonera== The [[Argentina national football team|national team]] has played several games in La Bombonera, including qualifying matches to the [[FIFA World Cup]]. The squad played the most games since the 1920s to the mid-1970s. Since the [[Estadio Antonio Vespucio Liberti|''Estadio Monumental'']] of [[Club Atlético River Plate|River Plate]] was completely refurbished for the [[1978 FIFA World Cup|1978 WC]], the [[Argentine Football Association]] fixtured the majority of Argentina's home games at that venue. That decision was based on the ''Monumental'' higher capacity and modern facilities in comparison with La Bombonera. Playing at Boca Juniors stadium, Argentina was only defeated in two games, having played a total of 27 matches, winning 18 and losing 2 with 7 ties. The squad scored 67 goals and only conceded 27.[http://www.rsssf.com/tablesa/arg-intres.html ARGENTINA NATIONAL TEAM ARCHIVE] by Héctor D. Pelayes on [[RSSSF]] Some of the official and friendly games played by Argentina at the stadium (as of 29 May 2018) are listed below: {| class="wikitable sortable" width="520px" |- ! width=150px| Game status ! width=170px| Date ! width=150px| Rival ! width=50px| Score |- | [[Copa Lipton]] || 14 Nov 1956 || {{fb|URU}} || 1–1 |- | [[1958 FIFA World Cup qualification|1958 FIFA WCQ]] || 20 Oct 1957 || {{fb|CHI}} || 4–0 |- | [[1970 FIFA World Cup qualification|1970 FIFA WCQ]] || 24 Aug 1969 || {{fb|BOL}} || 1–0 |- | [[1970 FIFA World Cup qualification|1970 FIFA WCQ]] || 31 Aug 1969 || {{fb|PER}} || 2–2 |- | Friendly || 8 Jan 1971 || {{fb|FRA}} || 3–4 |- | Copa R. Castilla || 27 Jul 1973 || {{fb|Peru}} || 3–1 |- | [[1974 FIFA World Cup qualification|1974 FIFA WCQ]] || 9 Sep 1973 || {{fb|BOL}} || 4–0 |- | [[1974 FIFA World Cup qualification|1974 FIFA WCQ]] || 7 Oct 1973 || {{fb|PAR}} || 3–1 |- | Friendly || 27 Feb 1977 || {{fb|HUN}} || 5–1 |- | Friendly || 29 May 1977 ||{{fb|POL}} || 3–1 |- | Friendly || 5 Jun 1977 || {{fb|GER}} || 1–3 |- | Friendly || 12 June 1977 || {{fb|ENG}} || 1–1 |- | Friendly || 18 Jun 1977 || {{fb|SCO}} || 1–1 |- | Friendly || 26 Jun 1977 || {{fb|FRA}} || 0–0 |- | Copa F. Bogado || 24 Aug 1977 || {{fb|PAR}} || 2–1 |- | Copa R. Castilla || 19 Mar 1978 || {{fb|PER}} || 2–1 |- | Friendly || 29 Mar 1978 || {{fb|BUL}} || 3–1 |- | Friendly || 5 Apr 1978 || {{fb|ROM}} || 2–0 |- | Friendly || 19 Apr 1978 || {{fb|IRL}} || 3–1 |- | Friendly || 3 May 1978 || {{fb|URU}} || 3–0 |- | Friendly || 26 Nov 1992 || {{fb|POL}} || 2–0 |- | [[1998 FIFA World Cup qualification|1998 FIFA WCQ]] || 16 Nov 1997 || {{fb|COL}} || 1–1 |- | 2012 [[Superclásico de las Américas|SA]] || 21 Nov 2012 || {{fb|BRA}} || 2–1 |- | [[2018 FIFA World Cup qualification|2018 FIFA WCQ]] || 5 Oct 2017 || {{fb|PER}} || 0–0 |- | Friendly || 29 May 2018 || {{fb|HAI}} || 4–0 |} ==Boca Museum== The Passion of Boca Juniors Museum ({{lang-es|Museo de la Pasión Boquense}}) was opened in 2001 during the Mauricio Macri's administration.{{cite web|last=Neumann|first=Jeannette|url=https://www.usatoday.com/sports/soccer/2008-05-01-554712659_x.htm|title=In Argentina, fans go wild for Boca Juniors|date=1 May 2008|publisher=[[USA Today]]|accessdate=2008-11-07}}{{cite web|url=http://travel.nytimes.com/travel/guides/central-and-south-america/argentina/buenos-aires/attraction-detail.html?vid=1154654620587 |title=Buenos Aires Attractions - Boca Juniors Stadium and Museum |publisher=[[New York Times]] |accessdate=2008-11-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070224011103/http://travel.nytimes.com/travel/guides/central-and-south-america/argentina/buenos-aires/attraction-detail.html?vid=1154654620587 |archivedate=February 24, 2007 }} It is located within the stadium, just below the grandstands. The Museum was built on two floors and chronicles the club's rise from [[1905 in Argentine football|1905]] (the year the club was established) to the present day. One of the exhibits in the museum is a giant football with 360-degree footage of the club's fans and players at a match. The museum also includes a [[Hall of fame]] and a large mural of Diego Maradona. Also included are non-football items such as the specially commissioned blue and gold guitar played by Lenny Kravitz when he performed at La Bombonera in 2005.{{cite web|url=http://www.fodors.com/world/south-america/argentina/buenos-aires/review-193396.html|title=Estadio Boca Juniors Review|publisher=[[Fodor's]]|accessdate=2008-11-08}}{{cite web|url=http://www.museoboquense.com/home.php |title=El Museo de la Pasión Bocquense |publisher=[[Club Atlético Boca Juniors]] |language=Spanish |accessdate=2008-11-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081109055733/http://www.museoboquense.com/home.php |archivedate=2008-11-09 |df= }} A giant statue of Boca Juniors' all-time topscorer, [[Martín Palermo]], was unveiled in 2011. Other former players who have their statues honoring them are [[Diego Maradona]] and [[Román Riquelme]][http://www.larazon.com.ar/deportes/Palermo-estatua-gigante_0_269700091.html "Palermo ya tiene su estatua gigante"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304202830/http://www.larazon.com.ar/deportes/Palermo-estatua-gigante_0_269700091.html |date=2016-03-04 }} ''Diario La Razón'', Fecha: 20/08/2011 A total of seven Boca Juniors idols have been honored by the club with their respective monuments, they are [[Guillermo Barros Schelotto]], [[Angel Clemente Rojas]], [[Silvio Marzolini]] and [[Antonio Rattín]], apart from Maradona, Palermo and Riquelme. [[Carlos Bianchi]] was the first Boca Juniors manager to be honored with a statue, when a monument of his figure was unveiled in October 2016. Bianchi won 9 titles during his two tenures on the club (1998–2003), becoming the most winning manager in Boca Juniors' history. Under Bianchi's coaching, the team also set a record of 40 matches unbeaten, the biggest since Argentine football became professional in [[1931 Argentine Primera División|1931]].[http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1945044-la-estatua-de-bianchi-la-manera-mas-simbolica-de-inmortalizarse-en-la-familia-xeneize El DT más ganador de la historia de Boca fue homenajeado con una pieza que se ubicará en el Museo del club; además, se llevó una réplica en miniatura] by Patricio Insúa, ''La Nación'', 7 Oct 2016 ==Redevelopment== There are planned improvements for the stadium, including measures to ease crowd congestion, use of new technology in the stadium and improved corporate facilities. These include:{{cite web|url=http://www.bocajuniors.com.ar/english/elclub_iso9001.php |title=First in the World - Processes that have been certified with the maximum distinction |publisher=[[Club Atlético Boca Juniors]] |accessdate=2008-11-07 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080528190403/http://www.bocajuniors.com.ar/english/elclub_iso9001.php |archivedate=2008-05-28 |deadurl=yes |df= }} *'''Main gate, museum and megastore''': Work is planned to be done on the main access to the stadium at 805 Brandsen which will include the construction of a [[megastore]], and to then connect the main access with the store and the club's museum. *'''Third tier''':Remodelling work to install further seating and improve spectator comfort. *'''Stadium gates''': Building work to improve access and prevent crowd congestion is underway. The first phase focuses on improving access to the executive boxes and premium seats. In addition, new software and hardware will improve access control with regard to safety and quickness to prevent crowd congestion. *'''Creation of a corporate area''': Businesses will have an area in the stadium with VIP service. One section in the second tier, is being re-designed with two executive boxes and more comfortable seating. The service will also provide businesses with [[season ticket]]s to allow them to invite clients. It also includes transportation, museum visits and catering services. ==In film== *Some scenes of the 1969 film ''[[Invasión]]'' were shot in the deserted stadium. *The Danish film ''[[SuperClásico]]'', has a part filmed in the stadium. == Further reading == * Gaffney, Christopher Thomas. ''[[Temples of the Earthbound Gods|Temples of the Earthbound Gods: Stadiums in the Cultural Landscape of Rio de Janeiro and Buenos Aires]]''. Austin: University of Texas Press, 2008. {{ISBN|978-0-292-72165-4}} ==See also== {{Portal|Buenos Aires}} * [[List of association football stadiums by capacity]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{commons category|Estadio Alberto J. Armando}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20081220132359/http://www.bocampeonweb.com.ar/english/bombonera3.htm Images of La Bombonera] *[http://www.football-match.de/buenos-aires/ Atmosphere at La Bombonera] {{Boca Juniors}} {{Primera División de Argentina venues}} {{Buenos Aires landmarks}} {{coord|34|38|8.34|S|58|21|52.74|W|region:AR-C_type:landmark|display=title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bombonera, La}} [[Category:1940 establishments in Argentina]] [[Category:Boca Juniors]] [[Category:Buildings and structures completed in 1940]] [[Category:Copa América stadiums]] [[Category:Football venues in Argentina]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1940]] [[Category:Sports venues in Buenos Aires]]

{{flagIOC|RU1|1912 Summer}} (1912) }} '''[[Poland]]''' competed at the '''[[1924 Winter Olympics]]''' in [[Chamonix]], [[France]]. ==Cross-country skiing== {{main|Cross-country skiing at the 1924 Winter Olympics}} ;Men {|class="wikitable" border="1" style="font-size:90%" |- !rowspan=2|Event !rowspan=2|Athlete !colspan=2|Race |- !Time !Rank |- |rowspan=2|18 km |[[Andrzej Krzeptowski (born 1903)|Andrzej Krzeptowski]] |align=center|1'43:02.8 |align=center|28 |- |[[Franciszek Bujak]] |align=center|1'42:13.0 |align=center|27 |- |50 km |[[Szczepan Witkowski]] |align=center|6'25:58 |align=center|21 |} ==Military patrol== {{main|Military patrol at the 1924 Winter Olympics}} {|class="wikitable" style="font-size:90%" |- !Athletes !Time !Shots on target !Final Time (-30s./hit) !Rank |- |[[Stanisław Chrobak]]
[[Stanisław Kądziołka]]
[[Szczepan Witkowski]]
[[Zbigniew Wóycicki]] |align="center"|DNF |align="center"|– |align="center"|– |align="center"|– |} == Nordic combined == {{main|Nordic combined at the 1924 Winter Olympics}} Events: * 18 km cross-country skiing * normal hill ski jumping The cross-country skiing part of this event was combined with the [[Cross-country skiing at the 1924 Winter Olympics|main medal event]] of cross-country skiing. Those results can be found above in this article in the cross-country skiing section. Some athletes (but not all) entered in both the cross-country skiing and Nordic combined event, their time on the 18 km was used for both events. One would expect that athletes competing at the Nordic combined event, would participate in the cross-country skiing event as well, as they would have the opportunity to win more than one medal. This was not always the case due to the maximum number of athletes (here: 4) could represent a country per event. The ski jumping (normal hill) event was held separate from the main medal event of ski jumping, results can be found in the table below. {|class="wikitable" style="font-size:90%" |- !rowspan="2"|Athlete !rowspan="2"|Event !colspan="4"|Ski Jumping !colspan="3"|Cross-country !colspan="2"|Total |- !Distance 1 !Distance 2 !Total points !Rank !Time !Points !Rank !Points !Rank |- |[[Andrzej Krzeptowski (born 1903)|Andrzej Krzeptowski]] |rowspan="2"|Individual |align="center"|32.5 |align="center"|33.0 |align="center"|13.312 |align="center"|17 |align="center"|1'43:02 |align="center"|5.750 |align="center"|20 |align="center"|9.531 |align="center"|19 |- |[[Franciszek Bujak]] |align="center"|– |align="center"|– |align="center"|– |align="center"|– |align="center"|1'42:13 |align="center"|6.250 |align="center"|18 |align="center"|DNF |align="center"|– |} == Ski jumping == {{main|Ski jumping at the 1924 Winter Olympics}} {|class="wikitable" style="font-size:90%" |- !rowspan="2"|Athlete !rowspan="2"|Event !colspan="3"|Jump 1 !colspan="4"|Jump 2 |- !Distance !Points !Rank !Distance !Points !Total !Rank |- |[[Andrzej Krzeptowski (born 1903)|Andrzej Krzeptowski]] |Normal hill |align="center"|33.0 |align="center"|12.750 |align="center"|21 |align="center"|32.0 |align="center"|12.167 |align="center"|12.458 |align="center"|21 |} ==Speed skating== {{main|Speed skating at the 1924 Winter Olympics}} ;Men {|class="wikitable" border="1" style="font-size:90%" |- !rowspan=2|Event !rowspan=2|Athlete !colspan=2|Race |- !Time !Rank |- |500 m |[[Leon Jucewicz]] |align=center|49.6 |align=center|17 |- |1500 m |[[Leon Jucewicz]] |align=center|2:42.6 |align=center|15 |- |5000 m |[[Leon Jucewicz]] |align=center|10:05.6 |align=center|16 |- |10,000 m |[[Leon Jucewicz]] |align=center|20:40.8 |align=center|14 |} '''All-round'''

{{Infobox swimming venue |name=Natatorio Carlos Berrocal |image=Natatario CAAM 1.JPG |imagesize= |caption=Main Pool |fullname=Recinto Universitario de Mayagüez Natatorium |nicknames=Piscina Alumni
Natatorio Centroamericano
Piscina del Colegio |city=[[Miradero]], [[Mayaguez, Puerto Rico|Mayagüez]], [[Puerto Rico|PR]] |coordinates={{coord|18|12|59.01|N|67|08|36.76|W|region:US-PR|display=inline,title}} |capacity=3,240http://mayaguez2010.com/es/instalaciones/deportivas/155-complejo-acuatico.html |built=2010 |opened=2010 |closed= |demolished= |architects= |home clubs=Tarzanes
Janes |pool1name=Olympic pool |pool2name=Warm up pool |pool3name=Diving pool |length1=50 m |length2=25 m |length3=25 m |width1= |width2=25 m |width3=35 m |deep1= |lanes1= }} The '''RUM Natatorium''' or ''Natatorio'' is a swimming complex on the [[University of Puerto Rico, Mayagüez Campus]]. The facility has three pools, the first is a 50-meter "Olympic" pool, a 25x25 meter warm up pool, and a diving pool which measures 25x35 meters that has dive platforms structures.http://10x10.upr.edu/?cat=23 ==History== The original Colegio pool ''Piscina Alumni'' (the "Alumni Pool") was located in the same site; it was demolished to make way for the new one. It was named for CAAM Alumni who provided funding for its construction. The ''Piscina Alumni'' was designed by [[Henry Klumb]] and it was inaugurated in 1966.http://www.uprm.edu/oiip/building.php?id=31&lang=2 The new complex was designed by the local firm '''Fuster + Partners – Architects'''.http://www.fusterpartners.com/porfolio/natatorio.htm The new natatorium cost $34 millions, which was paid by the "Autoridad para el Financiamiento de Infraestructura (AFI)". The pool will be used for the Swimming Events such as [[Swimming at the 2010 Central American and Caribbean Games|swimming]], [[Diving at the 2010 Central American and Caribbean Games|diving]], [[Synchronized swimming at the 2010 Central American and Caribbean Games|synchronized swimming]], and [[Water polo at the 2010 Central American and Caribbean Games|water polo]] at the [[2010 Central American and Caribbean Games]], and afterward they will pass to the University. This pool served as the main venue for the 2011 [[CCCAN]]. ==Gallery== File:Natatorio Afuera.JPG|A view of the jacuzzi File:Natatorio clavado.JPG|View of the diving platforms. File:Warmup pool.JPG|Warmup Pool File:Natatorio scoreboard.JPG|Scoreboard ==References== {{Portal|Puerto Rico}} {{Reflist}} {{University of Puerto Rico at Mayaguez}} {{2010 Central American and Caribbean Games venues|state=collapsed}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Natatorio Rum}} [[Category:College swimming venues in the United States]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Mayagüez, Puerto Rico]] [[Category:Swimming venues]] [[Category:Sports venues in Puerto Rico]] [[Category:University of Puerto Rico at Mayagüez]] [[Category:2010 Central American and Caribbean Games venues]] [[Category:2010 establishments in Puerto Rico]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2010]] {{PuertoRico-sports-venue-stub}}

'''Regional football federations of Ukraine''' is associated members of [[Football Federation of Ukraine]] in [[regions of Ukraine]]. In 2000 Football Federation of Ukraine created Council of Regions for the development of football in the regions throughout the country. It was dissolved in 2010. == Description == There are 24 active members, while membership of other 3 association is suspended due to the 2014 Russian invasion of Ukraine. Each region conducts its own championship, while most of them has also the second and the third tiers of league competitions. Each region also conducts a regional cup competitions as well as some additional regional tournaments. Along with it each regional federation has several smaller regional federations of its own (raion and city federations). Note that the Sevastopol City Football Federation cooperates with the Crimean Republican Football Federation and often teams from [[Sevastopol]] compete in the championship of the peninsula. Due to the 2014 Russian invasion of Ukraine, several regions were forced to suspend all sports competition due to war conditions. Republican Crimean Football Federation was raided and under the UEFA Special Commission mediation transferred to the [[Russian Football Union]]. Later it was renamed as Crimean Football Union. In 2016 Football Federation of Ukraine revived the Football Federation of Crimea in [[Kherson]]. Football competitions in [[Luhansk Oblast]] were conducted under auspices of pro-Russian separatist administration ([[Luhansk People's Republic]]), while in [[Donetsk Oblast]] competitions were resumed under united championship of Donbas. {| class="wikitable" |- ! revision.text:
[[File:Donald R. Deskins.png|thumb|[[Donald R. Deskins]] in a three-point stance.]] '''Stance''' is the position an [[American football]] player adopts when a play begins. There are three common stances used by [[Lineman (American football)|linemen]]: two-point, three-point, and four-point. The stance names reference the number of points where a player's body is touching the ground while down in the stance. Each technique has its own strengths and weaknesses; therefore, each one is used accordingly in different situations. Furthermore, stances are taught and used differently depending on the level of competition (little league football, high school football, college football, etc.).
==Overview== In the [[National Football League]] (NFL), the average amount of plays per game is over 60 per team.<ref name=NFLS>[http://www.teamrankings.com/nfl/stat/plays-per-game Rankings, Predictions, Picks and Odds for NBA, NCAAB, NFL, NCAAF and MLB], TeamRankings.com, 26 January 2011.</ref> This means that, in one game, a lineman playing the entire time could enter a stance more than 60 times. However, it is not likely to be the same stance every time. Furthermore, it is important to remember that the offensive team must remain still for one second prior to the ball being snapped. This means that once an offensive player has become set in a stance, he must stay in it until the ball is snapped and the play begins. Additional motion can result in a [[false start]] penalty.<ref name=NFLP>[http://www.nfl.com/rulebook/positionofplayers Rule Book: Position of Players at Snap], NFL.com, 26 January 2011.</ref> Defensive players, on the other hand, are permitted to shift as much as they want before a play. It is possible for a [[defensive lineman]] to line up in one stance and then change to another just before the play begins. He can even shift his body to another place.
==Variations== Commonly used stances are the two-point, [[Three-point stance|three-point]], and four-point.
==Two-point stance== The two-point variation is the most upright stance. Another name for the stance is the universal stance. The two-point is used by [[offensive linemen]] to facilitate better pass blocking because it increases their initial field of vision and gives more reaction time (to stay in front of a rushing player). Consequently, it is usually only used in a situation that will require passing.<ref name=3SOL>Hutchison, Coach. [http://www.active.com/football/Articles/The_3_Stances_of_Offensive_Linemen.htm "The 3 Stances of Offensive Linemen"], 24 January 2011.</ref> Some defensive linemen employ this stance to pass rush because they naturally obtain more quickness and agility out of it (particularly the [[defensive end]]s).
===Technique=== The "two-points" on the ground in this stance are just the feet. They are placed shoulder width apart pointing forward. One of the feet is staggered back, for an o-lineman this will be the foot away from the ball; for a d-lineman it will be the foot towards the ball. While in this stance the player's center of gravity will be slightly lowered by bending at the knees and waist. Weight is kept away from the heels to promote quickness and agility out of the stance in any direction.<ref name="3SOL"/>
==Three-point stance== The most common variation is the [[three-point stance]]. The purpose of this stance is to give the player leverage and allow more of their legs' power to be used. This is the offensive lineman's most used stance. It allows them to easily stay low and move in any direction at the snap of the ball. The interior defensive lineman use this stance for the same reason; however, it is usually slightly adjusted.
===Technique=== The added "point" is the player's strong hand on the ground (the down-hand). In higher divisions of play, ambidexterity between down-hands is required. A player entering the stance begins in a two-point stance; the player's staggered foot will be on the same side as the down-hand. The player then bends the knees and waist until the thighs and back are nearly parallel to the ground. The down-hand is merely an anchoring point for offensive linemen; typically, very little weight is put onto it. Offensive linemen may have to move in any direction so it is counterproductive to put weight on their down-hand (this only facilitates forward movement.) However, defensive players usually put more weight on their down-hand to have a more explosive start as they almost always go forward. This gives them the power of their legs coupled with forward momentum for a stronger push.
==Four-point stance== The least common variation is the four-point stance. This stance is used for maximum explosion and leverage in one direction (straight ahead of the player). Offensive linemen will typically only use it if they need to force the line forward only inches. Interior defensive lineman will use it to keep this push from happening.<ref name="3SOL"/>
===Technique=== The added "point" in this stance is the other arm. It is simply a three-point with the other hand put down. However, the hands in this case are allowed as much of the body's weight as the feet.<ref name="3SOL"/>
==Proposed bans== The three-point stance has become a staple in every football game. However, this has drawn attention to the danger it puts players in. The NFL has gained bad reputation because of the players' long-term and sometimes life-threatening complications brought about by head injuries. The NFL's commissioner, [[Roger Goodell]], has stated the possibility of banning the three-point stance because it makes linemen more likely to initiate head-to-head contact.<ref name=3PSB>{{cite news| url= http://www.bostonherald.com/sports/football/other_nfl/view.bg?articleid=1231381 |agency= Associated Press |title= Roger Goodell: Ban on 3-point Stance Possible |newspaper= [[Boston Herald]] |date= 8 February 2010 |accessdate= 24 January 2011}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}} {{Gridiron football maneuvers}} [[Category:American football terminology]]

{{Infobox rugby team | teamname = TJ Sokol Mariánské Hory | image = Smhrugby.jpg | imagesize = 200px | fullname = Tělocvičná jednota Sokol Mariánské Hory | location = [[Ostrava]], [[Czech Republic]] | ground = | founded = 1947 | president = {{flagicon|CZE}} Mgr. Dalibor Kereškéni | coach = {{flagicon|CZE}} Robert Vann | league = [[KB První Liga]] | pattern_la1=| pattern_b1=| pattern_ra1=| leftarm1=000000| body1=000000| rightarm1=000000| shorts1=000000| socks1=000000| }} '''TJ Sokol Mariánské Hory''' is a [[Czech Republic|Czech]] [[Rugby union|rugby]] club based in [[Mariánské Hory]], Ostrava. They currently play in the [[KB První Liga]].
==History== The club was founded in 1947. On 4 July of that year, they played their first match against a team called Slavia Brno.
In 1949 the club played against CFR Bucharest, their first match against opponents outside Czechoslovakia.
In 1979 they reached the final of the Czechoslovak Cup, losing to [[Praga Rugby]] 34-14.
More recently, in 2005, they won the Overton International Festival in [[Overton, Hampshire|Overton]], England.
==Historical names== * Sokol Vítkovické Železárny (1947–53) * Baník VŽKG Ostrava (1953–56) * VŽKG Ostrava (1956–60) * Lokomotiva Ostrava (1960–97) * Sokol Mariánské Hory (1998-)
==External links== *[http://www.ostrava.rugby.cz/ TJ Sokol Mariánské Hory] *{{cs icon}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20110719003832/http://www.rugbyunion.cz/rocenka-1926-2006de-80-let-ceskeho-ragby/100611/rocenka_80_let_ragby_1.pdf 80 let Českého Ragby (80 years of Czech Rugby)]

{{Shooting-sport-stub}} '''Target sprint''' is a [[shooting sport]] discipline that combines medium-range run (3 × 400 m) and [[air gun]] shooting.<ref>[http://www.issf-sports.org/news.ashx?newsid=2860 ISSF - The Target Sprint discipline made its official debut in Suhl]</ref><ref>[http://britishshooting.org.uk/getting-involved/title=What_Is_Target_Sprint&d=1132 Getting Involved | British Shooting]</ref> The rules are based on [[biathlon]].
== See also == * [[Modern pentathlon]]
== References == <references/>
== External links == * [http://britishshooting.org.uk/target-sprint/ Target Sprint | British Shooting]

{{Infobox stadium | name = UCF Soccer and Track Stadium | nickname = | logo_image = | image = UCF Soccer and Track Stadium.jpg | image_size = 250px | caption = | location = [[Orlando, Florida|Orlando]], [[Florida]],
[[United States]] | coordinates = {{coord|28.60765|-81.19520 |format=dms |region:US-FL_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = | opened = 1991
{{small|({{Age in years|1991}} years ago)}} | renovated = 2011
{{small|({{Age in years|2011}} years ago)}} | owner = [[University of Central Florida]] | operator = University of Central Florida | surface = Natural Grass / Martin Surface{{cite web|url=http://www.ucfknights.com/facilities/ucf-track-soccer-complex.html|title=UCF Knights - Official Athletics Site - Facilities {{pipe}} UCF Soccer and Track Complex|publisher=}} | scoreboard = | cost = | architect = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | capacity = 2,000 | suites = | record_attendance = 2,706 {{small|(2013)}} | dimensions = {{convert|347|ft|m}} x {{convert|200|ft|m}}
8 lane, 400 meter track | acreage = | tenants = [[University of Central Florida|UCF]] [[UCF Knights|Knights]] ([[NCAA]]) (1991–present)
[[UCF Knights men's soccer|Men's soccer]], [[UCF Knights women's soccer|women's soccer]], [[UCF Knights track and field|track and field]], cross country
[[Kraze United]] ([[National Premier Soccer League|NPSL]]) (2015) | publictransit = UCF Transit Center, [[File:LYNX transportation logo.svg|50px|Lynx|link=Lynx (Orlando)]] | website = [http://www.ucfknights.com/facilities/ucf-track-soccer-complex.html Official site] }} The '''UCF Soccer and Track Stadium''' is a [[Multi-purpose stadium|multi-purpose]] [[stadium]] located on the main campus of the [[University of Central Florida]] in [[Orlando, Florida]], United States. The 2,000-seat stadium is home to the [[UCF Knights]] [[track and field]], [[Cross country running|cross country]] and [[soccer]] teams. The Knights compete in the [[American Athletic Conference]] (The American). ==Location== [[File:Knights Plaza Wide.jpg|left|170px|thumb|[[Knights Plaza]], part of UCF's Athletic Village]] UCF's Soccer and Track Stadium is located on the northern edge of the University of Central Florida's {{convert|1415|acre|ha|adj=on}} main campus, which is approximately {{convert|13|mi|km|0}} northeast of downtown Orlando and {{convert|55|mi|km|0}} southwest of [[Daytona Beach, Florida|Daytona Beach]].{{cite web|url=http://www.iroffice.ucf.edu/character/current.html |title=Facts About UCF |accessdate=2010-11-13 |publisher=UCF Office of Institutional Research |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120415043957/http://www.iroffice.ucf.edu/character/current.html |archivedate=2012-04-15 |df= }} The stadium is located within [[Knights Plaza]], which is a part of UCF's Athletic Village. The Plaza is home to the [[CFE Arena]], the indoor arena of [[UCF Knights#Basketball|UCF Knights basketball]], and [[The Venue at UCF|The Venue]], home of the Knights [[volleyball]] program and [[Spectrum Stadium]]. Also located in Knights Plaza are [[John Euliano Park]], the home field of [[UCF Knights baseball|Knights baseball]], and [[University of Central Florida|The Towers]] residence halls, which house 2,000 UCF students, including student-athletes.{{cite news | url=http://issuu.com/ucfmbbguide/docs/golf_guide | title=UCF Men's 2009-2010 Golf Yearbook | publisher=University of Central Florida | accessdate=2010-11-13}} ==History== [[File:UCFTrackandSoccerComplex.jpg|left|thumb|170px|The field and the old stand, built in 2004, still in use.]] The stadium was built in 1991, and during the summer of 2004, the track was resurfaced and enhanced. The complex underwent another further renovation in 2008, adding long jump and triple jump pits as well as an expanded throwing area. In 2011, the stadium was heavily renovated, boasting a 2,000 seat capacity with a new 1,475-seat stand, press box, {{convert|7,500|sqft|m2}} clubhouse, restrooms and new entrance on the west side of the facility. The original 500-seat stand was retained as a visitors' stand.{{cite web|url=http://ucfathletics.cstv.com/sports/w-track/spec-rel/050311aaa.html|title=UCF to Open New Stadium With Thursday's Twilight Meet - UCF Knights - Official Athletics Site|publisher=}} The renovated stadium opened in May 2011. The soccer field is made of natural grass and measures {{convert|347|ft|m}} x {{convert|200|ft|m}}. The complex includes throwing areas for the [[hammer throw|hammer]], [[discus throw|discus]], [[shot put]], [[long jump]], and [[triple jump]] pits. ==International soccer matches== UCF Soccer and Track Stadium hosted its first international soccer match on January 16, 2015.{{cite web|last1=Squizzato|first1=Daniel|title=CanMNT: Canada set January friendlies against Iceland in Orlando|url=http://www.mlssoccer.com/news/article/2014/12/17/canmnt-canada-set-january-friendlies-against-iceland-orlando|website=MLSsoccer.com|publisher=Major League Soccer|accessdate=17 December 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141217201029/http://www.mlssoccer.com/news/article/2014/12/17/canmnt-canada-set-january-friendlies-against-iceland-orlando|archivedate=December 17, 2014}} {| class="wikitable" |- ! Date ! Result ! Competition |- | January 16, 2015 || {{fb|CAN}} 1–2 {{fb|ISL}}|| Friendly{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.us/gamecast/413243/gamecast.html|title=Canada v Iceland|work=ESPNFC.com}} |- | January 19, 2015 || {{fb|CAN}} 1–1 {{fb|ISL}}|| Friendly{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.us/gamecast/413439/gamecast.html|title=Canada v Iceland|work=ESPNFC.com}} |} ==See also== *[[UCF Knights]] *[[University of Central Florida]] *[[List of University of Central Florida alumni|University of Central Florida Alumni]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://ucfathletics.cstv.com/facilities/ucf-track-soccer-complex.html UCF Soccer and Track Stadium] Information at UCF Athletics *[http://ucfknights.com/ UCF Knights] Athletics website *[http://www.ucf.edu/ University of Central Florida] School website {{University of Central Florida}} {{American Athletic Conference soccer venue navbox}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ucf Soccer and Track Stadium}} [[Category:University of Central Florida]] [[Category:UCF Knights]] [[Category:Athletics (track and field) venues in Florida]] [[Category:College track and field venues in the United States]] [[Category:Sports venues in Orlando, Florida]] [[Category:Soccer venues in Florida]] [[Category:National Premier Soccer League stadiums]] [[Category:1991 establishments in Florida]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1991]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox sports competition event | competition = [[Women's World Chess Championship]] 2015 | governing_body = [[FIDE]] | image = Mariya Muzychuk 2013.jpg | alt = Mariya Muzychuk | caption = [[Mariya Muzychuk]], winner of the 2015 championship. | venue = | location = [[Sochi]], [[Russia]] | dates = 16 March – 7 April 2015 | competitors = 64 | nations = | champion = {{flagicon|UKR}} [[Mariya Muzychuk]] | win_score = | previous = [[Women's World Chess Championship 2013|2013]] | next = [[Women's World Chess Championship 2016|2016]] }} The [[Women's World Chess Championship]] was held from 16 March to 7 April 2015 in [[Sochi]], [[Russia]]. It was a 64-player [[knockout tournament]]. It was originally scheduled from 11 to 31 October 2014 but problems in finding a sponsor and host city eventually forced international chess organisation [[FIDE]] to announce the postponement of the Championship on 24 September 2014,{{cite web|url=http://www.fide.com/component/content/article/1-fide-news/8293-womens-world-championship-2014.html |title=Women's World Championship 2014 |publisher=FIDE |date=2014-09-24 |accessdate=2015-04-06}} scheduling it for early 2015 in Sochi.{{cite web|title=Women's World Championship to Take Place in Sochi|url=http://chess-news.ru/node/17444|publisher=chess-news.ru|accessdate=27 November 2014|date=25 November 2014}} The unclear state of the tournament was highly criticised by the [[Association of Chess Professionals]] (ACP).{{cite web|title=Open Letter to FIDE President Mr.Kirsan Ilyumzhinov |url=http://www.chessprofessionals.org/content/open-letter-fide-president-mrkirsan-ilyumzhinov|publisher=chessprofessionals.org|accessdate=27 August 2014|date=26 August 2014}} In the final, Ukrainian [[Mariya Muzychuk]], seeded 8th, defeated Russian [[Natalia Pogonina]], seeded 31st. As a result of this victory, Muzychuk was awarded the title of [[Grandmaster (chess)|Grandmaster]] (GM), qualified for the [[Chess World Cup 2015|FIDE World Cup 2015]], and earned the right to defend her title in a [[Women's World Chess Championship 2016|2016 match]] against the winner of the [[FIDE Women's Grand Prix 2013–14|Women's FIDE Grand Prix Series 2013-14]], [[Hou Yifan]]. ==Participants== [[File:Natalia Pogonina.jpg|thumb|180px|[[Natalia Pogonina]], finalist of the championship]] The players were selected through national chess championships, zonal tournaments and continental chess championships. 51 players from women's continental and zonal qualifiers:[http://www.fide.com/FIDE/handbook/regulationsWWCC.pdf Fide.com] - Regulations of the WWCC Cycle Europe 28,{{cite web|url=http://www.fide.com/images/stories/NEWS_2013/FIDE/Congress/Annexes/Annex_35.pdf |format=PDF |title=List of competitors : 2012 & 2013 |publisher=FIDE |accessdate=2015-04-06}} Asia 12, Americas 8 and Africa 3. The qualified players were announced on 22 January 2015, subject to signing the contract.{{cite web|url=http://www.fide.com/component/content/article/1-fide-news/8512-womens-world-championship-2015-players-contract.html |title=Women's World Championship 2015: Player's Contract |publisher=FIDE |date=2015-01-22 |accessdate=2015-04-06}} Notably, women's world number one and defending champion Hou Yifan from [[China]] opted not to play, because of a prior commitment to a chess tournament in [[Hawaii]].{{cite web|url=http://www.yourgibraltartv.com/society/8519-feb-05-hou-yifan-won-t-defend-world-champion-title-in-2015 |title=Feb 05 - Hou Yifan Won't Defend World Champion Title in 2015 |publisher=Yourgibraltartv.com |date=2015-02-05 |accessdate=2015-04-06}}{{cite web|url=http://www.chess.com/blog/hawaiichessfestival/challenge-hou-yifan-gareev-and-shankland-in-hawaii |title=Challenge Hou Yifan, Timur Gareev and Sam Shankland in Hawaii! |publisher=Chess.com |date=2015-01-25 |accessdate=2015-04-06}} Also absent from the world top-10 were [[Nana Dzagnidze]] and [[Kateryna Lagno]] (they were replaced by two spots from E13). The participating players were seeded by their March 2015 [[FIDE rating]] (shown after the players below). Three former world champions were in the field: [[Alexandra Kosteniuk]] seeded 5th, [[Antoaneta Stefanova]] 9th and [[Anna Ushenina]] 15th. {{col-begin}} {{col-2}}
  1. {{flagathlete|[[Humpy Koneru]]|India}}, GM, 2581 (R)

{{col-end}} === Qualification paths === {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} *WC: Semi-finalists of the [[Women's World Chess Championship 2012]] and runner-up of [[Women's World Chess Championship 2013|2013]] *J12 and J13: [[World Junior Chess Championship|World Junior Champions]] 2012 and 2013 *R: Rating (average of all published ratings from February 2013 to January 2014 was used) (5) *E12 and E13: [[European Individual Chess Championship|European Individual Championships]] 2012 and 2013 (28) *AM: [[American Continental Chess Championship]] 2014 {{col-2}} *AS12 and AS13: [[Asian Chess Championship]]s 2012 and 2013 *AF: [[African Chess Championship]] 2013 (3) *[[U.S. Women's Chess Championship|Z2.1]] (3), [[Canadian Chess Championship|Z2.2]], Z2.3, Z2.4, Z2.5, Z3.1, Z3.2, Z3.3, Z3.4, Z3.5 (4), [[Oceania Chess Championship|Z3.6]], [[Indian Chess Championship|Z3.7]]: Zonal tournaments *PN: [[FIDE]] President nominee (2) {{col-end}} ===Nationalities in the field=== Russia sent the most players with ten, one more than China. Note that 26 of the players came from countries which were former Soviet republics. {| class=wikitable |- ! Europe (35)!!Asia/Oceania (18)!!Americas (8)!!Africa (3) |- | {{ARM}} (2) || {{AUS}} (1) || {{ARG}} (2) || {{ALG}} (1) |- | {{BUL}} (1) || {{BAN}} (1) || {{CAN}} (1) || {{EGY}} (2) |- | {{FRA}} (2) || {{CHN}} (9) || {{CUB}} (1) || rowspan=11| |- | {{GEO}} (6) || {{IND}} (3) || {{PER}} (1) |- | {{GER}} (1) || {{INA}} (1) || {{USA}} (3) |- | {{HUN}} (1) || {{IRI}} (1) || rowspan=8| |- | {{LIT}} (2) || {{KAZ}} (1) |- | {{POL}} (1) || {{VIE}} (1) |- | {{RUS}} (10) || rowspan=5| |- | {{SCO}} (1) |- | {{SWE}} (1) |- | {{TUR}} (2) |- | {{UKR}} (5) |} ==Schedule and prize money== [[File:Chess Championship 2015 (Women).png|thumbnail|right|FIDE president [[Kirsan Ilyumzhinov]] (right), awaiting the second round.]] Two days per match were followed by possible tie-breaks on the next day if the match was tied. The only rest day was 1 April the day after the semi-finals. The total prize-money was 450,000 US dollars, the same as in 2010 and 2012.{{cite web | url=http://www.chess.com/news/womens-world-championship-about-to-take-off-3525?page=2 | title=Women's World Championship About To Take Off (But Hou Yifan Doesn't Play) | publisher=chess24.com | date=15 March 2015 | accessdate=16 March 2015}} {| class="wikitable" |- !align="right"|Round ! style="text-align:center;"|Matches !align="left"|Tie-breaks !align="left"|Prize-money (US$) |- |align=right|First round |align=center|17–18 March |align=center|19 March |align=right|3,750 |- |align=right|Second round |align=center|20–21 March |align=center|22 March |align=right|5,500 |- |align=right|Third round |align=center|23–24 March |align=center|25 March |align=right|8,000 |- |align=right|Quarter-finals |align=center|26–27 March |align=center|28 March |align=right|12,000 |- |align=right|Semi-finals |align=center|29–30 March |align=center|31 March |align=right|20,000 |- |align=right|Final |align=center|2–5 April |align=center|6 April |align=right|loser 30,000
winner 60,000 |} ==Results== ===Final match=== {{Chess diagram small | tright | |rd | | || | |kd| | | | pd | |rl|pd|qd| | | |pl| pd | | | | | | | |bl | | | nd | | | | | | | | pl| | |pl | | | ql | | kl| | | || | | || | | | | | | || |Position after move 40 in game 4 of the final.{{cite web | url =http://www.chess.com/news/mariya-muzychuk-wins-womens-world-championship-5657 |title=Mariya Muzychuk Wins Women's World Championship|publisher=[[Chess.com]]| date=5 April 2015| accessdate =8 April 2015}} }} The final was the only match of the tournament which consisted of four classical games (from 2 to 5 April 2015), played on consecutive days with a rest-day between the semi-final tie-breaks and match 1. Eventual tie-breaks, if needed, were scheduled to play on 6 April 2015, in the same manner as the whole tournament: two rapid games (25+10), i.e. 25 minutes for the whole game plus 10 seconds increment, the two rapid games (10+10), two blitz games (5+3) and an [[Armageddon chess|armageddon]] decider. Pogonina had the white pieces in the first game. Before the final they had met only once, in the 2007 [[European Individual Chess Championship]], which ended in a draw.{{cite web|url=http://www.chessgames.com/perl/chess.pl?yearcomp=exactly&year=&playercomp=either&pid=&player=pogonina&pid2=&player2=mariya+muzychuk&movescomp=exactly&moves=&opening=&eco=&result= |title=* Chess game search engine |publisher=Chessgames.com |date= |accessdate=2015-04-06}} In the final game 4, white pieces belonged to Muzychuk, who opened the game with her favorite 1.е4.{{cite web | url =https://www.fide.com/component/content/article/1-fide-news/8617-womens-world-championship-2015-round-4-tie-breaks.html|title=Mariya Muzychuk is Women's World Chess Champion |publisher=FIDE| date=5 April 2015| accessdate =7 April 2015}} Pogonina responded with her favorite 1…е5. In the [[Scotch Four Knights Game]] she tried to avoid the main variations by putting the bishop to b4 via c5. The idea allowed Black to duck the home preparation of Muzychuk. White, however, achieved a spatial advantage and overall more favorable game after the opening. Later White decided to advance kingside pawns, weakening own king. The Black also had pawn weaknesses and a sharp and dynamically balanced position emerged. On the move 41 Muzychuk carried out a simplifying combination, transposing to an [[Chess endgame|endgame]] with two strong [[passed pawn]]s against a knight. Pogonina was left with no winning chances, and the game ended in a [[Draw (chess)|draw]] on the move 56 after the move repetition. :{| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |+Women's World Chess Championship Final 2015 |- ! !!
